title: How to stop eating junk food - Quora

response.answer_text: Hey, Here are 8 effective ways to stop eating Junk food: -Read about JUNK FOOD and know EXACTLY how they affect your body. Sure, we know that cola is bad for us. But do you really know how bad can it for you? Watch this video. -Never, ever, go to the supermarket empty stomach: I have seen this pattern time and time again. When I am hungry almost every time, I pick at least few extra items of unhealthy stuff like biscuits etc. So next time have a nice meal and then do your grocery shopping:) -Tell your friends and family NOT to give you sweets, or other unhealthy stuff during festivities. Instead tell them to gift yor fitness bands, gym memberships or massage vouchers. It may seem odd at first to you and to them, but they might just appreciate your creativity. Or probably you can be the first mover and gift them a healthy gift and in most cases they will oblige by doing the same! -Whenever visiting KFC, McD always order less or just a single burger and tell your partner or friend that you will share it. Usually its the craving. After a bit or two or three bites later it goes away. Maybe you can eat few almonds and a piece of fruit before eating junk. -Know this: You cannot completely stop yourself from eating junk. Just apply the 80/20 rule. Eat exceptionally well 80–90% of the time and then cheat on Junk ( don't go crazy) once a week. I swear to GOD I enjoy eating junk more than you as I eat them once a month and really saviour every bite. Sometimes, I just don't feel like and months pass without me eating jUNK. But if I have cravings i do snack on them from time to time. -Don't order fries or those thick vanilla shakes with your burgers. Seriously! -Start your day well, by eating something healthy. This requires planning on your part. If you cannot find eggs in the morning don't be surprised you binge on waffles and pancakes and this will probably spiral into a bad day of eating almost every time. -Teach yourself to cook more at home or simply delegate the task if you are not the cooking types! We tend to eat fast/junk food usually when there is no good-delicious home made alternatives available. You’ll be blown away if you drink one of my smoothies! Don't forget even pizzas can be made with whole four and tons of fresh veggies and free meat. Just find someone to do the dirty work…haha! Good luck:)

First, rest assured, your desire to eat junk is basically an addiction. When you try to quit it, you feel HORRIBLE! Your body has become acclimated to the quick fixes it gets from sugar, salt, etc. You are not going to feel good as you try to eat healthier, for a short time. I think that’s one thing people get wrong: they think if they adopt a healthy diet, they’re going to feel GREAT on day one. Chances are they will feel like POO on day one through at least four, if not six or seven! You can take two approaches to eating healthier. One option is to gradually reduce the junk in your diet, replacing it gradually with healthier foods. If you would have eaten a sugary cereal for breakfast, you instead have sweetened yogurt and some healthy protein. If you would have had a burger and fries for lunch, you instead have a lighter sandwich and maybe some sweet potato fries. Etc. From there you keep working yourself into healthier and healthier options. The second option is to find a time period where you can afford to be grumpy and go “cold turkey.” Cut all added sugar, salt, fat, etc., and be miserable for 4–7 days while your body adjusts. Eat those veggies and lean proteins you know are good for you exclusively, and be angry and upset about it in privacy. If you have the option to take a week off from work and do this, I recommend this approach, as the “miserable period” passes pretty quickly. In either case, there are going to be some things that surprise and frustrate you. If you eat a lot of sugary foods now, and cut back on those, you are going to have to pee ALL THE TIME. When sugars are stored (as glycogen), they are stored bound up with a lot of water (3–4 parts water to 1 part usable sugar), and when your body starts to release those sugars, they release a TON of water with them. You will also be thirsty AF because of this process. You will also likely be hungry every few hours as your body burns through the complex carbs and proteins you give it and demands quicker fixes. It’s all normal and no reason to give up, but can be hard to deal with depending on how your workday normally goes (if you have limited bathroom and meal breaks, it can be hard, which is why I suggest doing it when you are off work for a while).

Well one way is to make a list of things you eat that you consider junk food. Decide which ones you will start to refrain from eating and try to be sincere and decisive when you scratch the item(s) off your list. Just a few … not too many. You have to be in a frame of mind that you will not eat that again for a least a year, no sooner, so you have to be honest with yourself when you put a scratch mark through it. Just one clear line through the item to remind yourself of your decision not to eat that. After a month or so you can choose 1 or more other items but only if you kept yourself from eating the items you’ve already chosen. Continue this process until you feel like you were able to complete your original goal and can continue. Maybe reserve a special thing you like to do or a special fruit you like to eat as a reward for successfully completing the task. Good luck. In my case, about 4 years ago I decided not to eat white bread, pasta, rice, sugary foods, grains, and excessive carbohydrates and I’ve been able to stick with my original decisions but it hasn’t been easy because temptation is all around. The other thing is good nutritious food will help me live longer and healthier and the quality of my life will be better so I think it is a good tradeoff. I still eat pizza once every month or two but it is insignificant compared to everything else I eat … not like eating junk food nearly every day and not giving my body a chance to recover. Given that there are many people on LCHF (Low Carb High Fat), IF (Intermittent Fasting) and Keto diets I feel safe in saying that sugar isn’t necessary for metabolic function and it seems like the brain, which normally uses glucose can adjust/adapt to using ketones instead. I wouldn’t go as far as eliminating all carbs from my diet because I tend to avoid extremes but I have modified existing diets to the following. I have gradually adopted IF dieting as part of my daily regimen and I’ve modified typical IF diet by separating meats (protein) and fatty foods (fats) from veggies (low glycemic carbs) and fruits. By separate I mean I eat one group one day and the other group the next. I eat reasonable portions and by separating the fats from carbs I’m also extending insulin response from everyday to once every 48 hours instead of every 24. This gives my blood glucose time to stay down and I can be in a state of using fats for energy instead of glucose. After my dinner I have 9 to 12 hours for my blood glucose to go down and then I should be in a state of ketosis if I allow myself to remain in that state by adhering to my fasting. Also I get the benefits/nutrients of both food groups.

response.answer_text: I could have written this just 60 days ago - you just described the same hell that I'm going through.  I'm now down over 40 pounds...losing it very slow, but I hear the right way.  The problem is, the thoughts of those foods don't go away.  I still use restaurants as place markers when explaining directions to people.  I have the same pep talk every morning...today is different.  At the time of eating, you don't really feel that bad.  When you're sitting with a full stomach in bed an hour later, you hate life and wondered how you could f**k up so bad. My answer (without being the expert) is that you can't force yourself.  An alcoholic can't force himself not to drink, a meth addict can't force herself to stop.  A smoker can't force themselves to stop.  You have an addiction.  Except, unlike the others, if you quit yours cold turkey...you die. The easy answer from all the experts is to stop doing it, lay fruit out (so it can attract flies and rot over the next two days), don't buy any when shopping, avoid fast food restaurants.  Stop putting food in your face.   Someone says stop eating, you're stomach is huge (and they're funny).  You say stop drinking and cheating on your wife (now things get seroius). Every day is a battle.  Get a partner to work with you or have a mentor who's been there before - like any other recovery program and CALL them when you have the urge.  You already know not to do it, but you can't reason with yourself.  They have a better chance of "forcing" you to fight the urge. I do this with my wife.  I taught her my evil ways...but at least she can stop at one piece of pizza.  We talk each other our of shit every night.  We cook our "healthy" meals together (in advance so they're convenient like junk food).  We walk the dogs together.  We limit restaurants to once every two weeks and really make it a treat. It's working so far, but I have gained more than this in a few months.  Even when you get fit, you're still fat.  Same as an alcoholic can be sober for 25 years and they're still an alcoholic - that's why they're always counting.  It's like a prison sentence where you put on stroke on the wall per day. I wish you well.

Summary: The more junk food you eat, in the form of either bad fats or quick-digesting carbs, the greater your body’s insulin hormone response and the faster your body's fats cells are ordered to draw nutrients out of the bloodstream to be stored in the fat cells. This conversion happens faster than normal for high-glycemic foods (i.e. those that are broken to glycogen faster by the body). And when fat cells are ordered to pull nutrients out of the bloodstream faster, a low blood sugar scenario arises and your brain triggers hungry pangs quite soon after you’ve eaten the junk food. With the combo of low blood sugar levels and hunger pangs triggered by the brain, you are made to crave more starchy, sugary foods because they are a faster converting source of energy. A viscous circle ensues and your initial intake of junk food leads to subsequent cravings for more junk food. The reality is that ,hard as it may be, you have to stop eating junk food in order to stop further cravings of junk food, if that makes sense. Longer version;For as long as I can remember there has been a misconception propagated that says 'fats are bad'. Candy companies have loved this spiel because now they use it as a marketing ploy - "our products are naturally fat-free".The truth is that fat is commonly misunderstood. Far from being an enemy, it's actually an evolutionary advantage. When we compare our ancestors, the Homo sapiens, to the Neanderthals, the latter were muscly folk, living mainly off meat and who evolved to have high metabolic rates. That's was fine until animal meat became scare to come by and suddenly they couldn't find the calorie intake needed to maintain metabolic activity. Neanderthals died out while Homo Sapiens survived. Our homo sapient ancestors, on the other hand, evolved to store energy in the form of adipose tissue (fats) that their bodies could use. So in times of famine our ancestors bodies relied on their fats stores to survive - it made for an evolutionary advantage! Key takeaway - we are born with fat cells and our bodies are predisposed to storing energy from food as fat. So it’s kind of weird then to be told that fat is bad right? You may have heard of the terms ‘glycemic index’ and ‘glycemic load’. These are indexes that measure how quickly foods get broken down into nutrients and absorbed into the bloodstream. High glycemic foods convert faster than low glycemic foods, and high glycemic foods increase blood sugar levels relatively quickly. Here’s the thing - almost everything we eat gets broken down eventually to glucose which enters the blood stream. Carbs are actually just sugars which get broken down to glucose. Proteins get broken down to amino acids first, but even these can be converted to glucose via a process called gluconeogenesis. Fats too can be converted to glucose through various biological processes. Here’s an important fact: Glucose = ATP. The human body actually has three distinct energy systems (I won’t go into the details here) i.e. three sources from where it can create energy. It’s common to say glucose = energy but that’s only partly true. Glucose = ATP = energy is more accurate. ATP is the vital molecule that your body’s cells use for energy but ATP can only be created if glucose is available. No glucose = no ATP = dead. So glucose isn’t the enemy. This is important to understand. Some people try to cut out all sugars and they do more harm than good to their bodies. But to be very clear: processed sugar and sweets are the worst thing you can put in your bodies folks. Worse than eating (good) fats. Processed sugar messes up your levels of insulin release and if you keep eating processed sugar then a) you are at risk of diabetes and b) you could end up getting stuck with insulin sensitivity, in which case you’re going to be stuck with weight gain. The important hormone in the body that influences weight gain is insulin. Insulin is released from the pancreas once food is eaten. The amount of insulin released depends on the glycemic load of the foods eaten. Higher glycemic loads lead to great amount of insulin being released. Without insulin you can’t correctly regulate blood glucose levels and you’ll be resigned to a life of being fat. If you eat high glycemic foods (i.e. junk food), your body will release correspondingly large amounts of insulin and insulin acts as a signal for your fat cells to pull nutrients out of the bloodstream. This uptake happens faster if you eat McDonalds fries, for example, and slower if you were to eat slow burning carbs (like steel cut oats), vegetables or meats. The faster the uptake of nutrients from the your bloodstream into fat cells, the greater the swing in your blood glucose levels. Let’s be clear, spikes in blood glucose levels are bad for you - they give you that low energy feeling and mess with your body’s insulin regulating mechanism. Low blood glucose levels are a trigger to your brain to say you're running low on fuel. In turn the brain sends signals telling you that you're hungry again. But this time you need foods that convert to energy faster which is why you crave starchy and sugary food a short while after eating junk food. The vicious cycle continues and junk food leads to more junk food being eaten. Bad fats and high glycemic carbs are eaten. Weight gain ensues.A key takeaway is that fats are not bad! Good fats are of the mono- and poly- unsaturated variety. Eat plenty of nuts like almonds and walnuts. Eat guacamole and put olive oil on your salads. Eat proteins and vegetables. Choose carbs with lower glycemic index measures. This is why regulating your blood sugar is so crucial and fast changes in blood sugar levels are bad. Quote: "it's not the process of over eating that makes you fat. It's the process of becoming fat that makes you overeat." - taken from book: always hungry? Is it easy to quit junk food? No. If yo.u have been eating junk food for a long time, you’re wired to crave it. It’s a force of habit. But try to pull back as much as you can, even if its just quitting junk food and processed sugars for just one day a week. Is it sustainable to stay off junk food forever? No. That’s not realistic. Instead try to get to a stage where 6 days a week you are junk food and processed sugar free. And then give yourself one day where you indulge (within reasonable limits!). That’s a much more sustainable approach if, like in my own case, you find your will power can’t fight your junk food urges for very long

Being able to stop eating junk food is not as easy as it may sound for some people, because of so many factors that are involved in it. Before we take into consideration any list of healthy, amazing foods and strategies that help with this, may want to set a bit of time aside and work on changing the mindset about how you view these foods you crave; you want to go deep to the root of the problem and tackle it effectively. CHANGE YOUR MINDSET Currently, You view these foods as highly appealing and you crave them ….. If you gradually begin seeing junk foods in a negative light based on the real data (e.g: negative consequences on health) you’re likely to start craving them less. Ways to STOP CRAVING JUNK FOODS Learn/ know which foods are highly processed and junk and make a list of those you want to eliminate.Accept the fact that all junk foods are highly processed foods and high in sugar/sodium chemicals, artificial colours, additives.Learn about the connection between these foods and chronic health problems such as heart disease, diabetes, obesity, cancer, food allergies.. There are so many studies that show evidence of health problems resulting from the consumption of these foods, such as this one: Added sugars drive coronary heart disease via insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia: a new paradigm Know that these foods are addictive; the food manufacture companies spend a lot of time and money researching for the perfect combination of tastes, flavours by combining many of these unhealthy chemicals to make you crave more as you eat.Read the labels -if you see a list of ingredients and chemicals you can’ t pronounce, leave it there, don’t buyEnter a grocery store after you ate, never when HUNGRY; it is way harder to buy healthy foods and stick with your list, when you are hungry and crave for certain foods; HAVE A GROCERY LIST AND STICK WITH IT Spend most of your money in the fresh fruits, vegetable section as well as fresh lean meats and whole grains (bread). In the frozen section, best buys are frozen vegetables and fruits (no additives).Did you know that 77 percent of American grocery purchases consist of either moderately or highly processed foods? many studies , like this one, will show that “Is the degree of food processing and convenience linked with the nutritional quality of foods purchased by US households? “ ………….and let’s not blame it all on our choices as highly processed foods (sugary foods /beverages, snacks, microwave meals) take a big chunk of our grocery stores.Replace foods that are high in GI (glycemic index)with foods that are low and medium GI, in moderation;Why? ……because Foods with a high GI (junk food included) are quickly digested carbohydrates can cause excessive hunger and stimulate brain parts involved in reward and cravings Low: 55 or less Medium: 56–69 High: 70 or more Low GI: all green vegetables, most fruits, kidney beans, chickpeas, lentils and bran breakfast cereals, whole-grain breads  Medium GI: sweet corn, carrots, raw pineapple, raisins, oat breakfast cereals, brown rice oat bran or rye bread  High GI: White rice (Jasmine, sticky..), white flour &whole wheat flour bread, bagels, waffles potatoes,(mashed, fried, baked) overripe banana, watermelon, rice cakes, soda crackers, sweetened beverages, sports drinks, processed breakfast cereals, white pasta Note: many highly processed foods such as cakes, desserts, junk foods fall into the High GI category Consuming foods that are low in GI is one of the secrets to long-term health, reducing the risk of chronic diseases such as heart disease diabetes. Conclusion When we get into the habit of eating more junk or highly processed foods, we have a lower desire for eating whole, natural foods. This can create a cycle of unhealthy eating habits. By following these simple ways that were mentioned before, you can gain control over your food choices, reduce cravings and live a healthier life.

FACT: Obesity accounts for 300,000 deaths a year in the U.S. ... into how junk food and fast food ... affect obesity, have found that there may be a ... between the number  Research into how junk food and fast food restaurants affect obesity, have found that there may be a relationship between the number of people per fast food restaurant and how many square miles there are between fast food restaurants located within your local area and obesity rates. The way in which we eat, and what we eat, is of vital importance to our state of health. The convenience and habitual nature of the problem mean that fast food consumption is so in-grained, that healthy eating is near impossible. There are no easy ways to fix junk food habits and make them into healthy habits, but I do have 7 quick strategies that you can easily put into place to start into motion your new lifestyle without junk food. I recommend implementing these one at a time, to ensure that you don't overload and burn yourself out.  1. Do your shopping every week. Make it a regular habit to do your groceries every single week on the same day. 2. Make a shopping list on the computer with all the regular foods that you buy, to ensure that you aren't going to run out of food at the end of the week, tempting you to reach for the fast food pamphlet, running out for take-away or buying unnecessary food items. 3. Don't starve yourself !!!!!!! Eat 6 small meals instead of 3 large ones, snacking on healthy foods such as a fat burning apple, protein packed, metabolism raising light salad with boiled eggs and flaxseed oil dressing.  4. Make food your hobby. Join a cookery class. There are often many community classes that you can enrol in inexpensively to learn how to prepare interesting food. 5. Unplug the TV at the point. You will be less likely to sit there and watch it aimlessly if you have to make a conscious effort to turn it on. Particularly around 6-8 pm, the junk food restaurants will advertise, watch a DVD during these times. A recent review of childhood obesity research, has, not surprisingly found that the amount of time you spend watching TV has a direct affect on being overweight. 6. Try this recipe when you are feeling peckish to curb your need to buy junk food, or feeling the urge to have a smoke. 2 eggs beaten1 Chopped lean bacon rasher - no fat.1 chopped canned tomato1/4 cup soy milk/low fat milk1 finely chopped leaf spinach/frozen spinachSprinkling of low fat cheese  Mix ingredients together in mixing bowl. Transfer into a microwave safe bowl and cook on high for 2 minutes or until eggs have solidified. Eat with a low GI bread. You'll find that depending on the quantity eaten, it can be a filling snack or light dinner. 7. When eating out. Avoid the restaurants with the all-you-can-eat option. These restaurants unfortunately encourage people to eat until they are bloated. Researchers found that 20% of weight gain among freshman University students could be attributed to their eating in the all-you-can-eat student dining halls. Be healthy 💖

Let me tell you, I love me some junk food and fast food and pretty much any food. I’m over 50 and my weight had been creeping up to unacceptable levels. I then found it nearly impossible to lose weight and feel healthy over the past 2 years…I was eating well but would give myself some cheat meals, a pizza with the kids…a donut here or there…chips and beer after a long day…I called them indulgences. I was also grazing all day long…breakfast, a snack or light meal at 10AM, lunch, another snack, something before dinner and then a late dinner. I’d grab a few almonds or walnuts thinking these are the good nuts… I would make protein shakes after the gym or pool and have a casein protein shake before bed…I thought protein was great for me…to lose weight. What I had not known is that I was no doubt jacking my insulin levels constantly…I was for sure becoming insulin intolerant…craving snack foods, hungry all the time…. I was in the gym and in the pool almost every day but I was still gaining weight and feeling old, tired and weak… I did a lot of research and started intermittent fasting and the keto diet. In the past month and a half my health and weight have done a 180 degree turn around. You have to just stop eating junk food, no cheat meals, no bread, no sugar, no potatoes or rice or beans…just really good whole foods that have good healthy fats and proteins. Vegetables are limited to things like broccoli, cabbage, peppers and cauliflower…Butter coffee, thick ass fatty steak, ribs and eggs and bacon are my typical foodstuffs. Get enough salt. Some folks feel poorly when they first start eating this way and it’s because you are lowering your insulin levels and as a result, you dump a lot of sodium (insulin hangs on to sodium)this can give you some flu like feelings…tired groggy achy… I entered into ketosis and am using mostly fat as my primary energy source…all that fat around my belly. My cravings for sweets, bread , beer and whisky are non existent….I’m never hungry, I’m able to concentrate like never before and I have tons of energy even from the moment I wake up…so yeah, keto and intermittent fasting. Check it out. A great source is Dr Ken Berry an American MD who has a Youtube channel.

This is an awesome question because all diets fall apart if you can't resist the cravings. I had a 0 | 1,000 recording fighting cravings for years. It was only in the past two years that I found a simple solution. I still lose from time to time, but I do win much more often than I lose. Be forewarned that what comes next will sound dumb. If you can survive the stupidity and do it, it may just help you overcome your cravings.  Find a quiet place and lay on the ground face down. No not your bed or couch ... right on the floor. You can put down a mat if you want. Lay there and do nothing. Experience whatever thoughts come into your mind. Experience whatever body sensations arise. Don't fight anything except the urge to get up off the floor. In essence you are doing a simple meditation. Lay there until the cravings go away. I know its hard to believe that they will actually go away, but they will. You beat the cravings by waiting them out. Now it only takes me 5 - 10 minutes. But I do remember that when I started and the cravings were insane, I laid there for a couple hours one time. Over time the time I had to lay on the ground decreased. Why the ground, why face down? I can lie to you and make up a reason for why this works, but the reality is that I don't know why. I tried to lay on the couch and bed. It didn't work. I tried to lay face up and it didn't work. I tried doing other things like going for a walk to distract myself. They didn't work. My best guess is that by laying face down on the ground I form some kind of energetic connection with the earth. I do feel some kind of connection in my heart with I lay facing down on the ground. I have heard before the cravings are addictive in nature. I have heard that we eat unhealthy food because we are attempting to fill a hole in our heart. Is this true? I don't know. But by laying face down on the ground I definitely feel relief emotionally. It is still a battle, but one I can win. Is it magic? Laying on the ground is not a magic solution. It is still a battle. But for some reason, when I lay on the ground it is a battle that I am able to win. Sometimes I am stubborn and feel that I no longer needed to do this and could handle the cravings on my own. In that case I lose almost every time. Luckily, after doing this for a year I very rarely get cravings. I know it's weird. Is it weird laying on the ground face down? Really weird. That's why I recommended that you do it in private. Unfortunately, if you live with family members, they will at some point catch you doing it. They may tell you its weird and they may gossip about you. So let's look at the worst case scenario ... your secret gets out. People think you're a little weird for laying on the ground when you have food cravings. You're not completely "normal." Being normal is being sick. When I went to medical school at Robert Wood Johnson, I had a mentor who was a doctor with 30 years of experience. He told me that almost everyone will get a chronic disease by the time they are 50. Developing a chronic disease like: diabetesheart diseaseobesityarthritisrenal failureMSAlzheimer's,cancerThat's normal. Being normal is being sick. Do you want to be normal or sick? I decided at that moment that I did not want to be normal. I did not want to get sick. I didn't want to work in a system that operated on the assumption that we would all get sick anyway. Self fulfilling prophecy anyone? So I dropped out of med school. What I have since learned is this: A poor diet is the single biggest contributing factor to the diseases listed above. We can get rid of or reduce the impact of these diseases with good food. But this kind of thinking is not normal. A health diet that is different from the American diet is not normal. And laying on the ground to help you deal with cravings and stick with that diet is definitely not normal. But do you want to be normal and sick, or a little weird but healthy and happy?

4 years back, I was completely addicted to junk food. I couldn’t go without my candy bar or bag of chips. It was not until much later that I realized junk food was very similar to any other addiction. It pleasures the reward centers in brain and stimulates release of dopamine, an addictive chemical [ref]. You know how long it takes to break a habit? 3 weeks. I went cold turkey on junk food and threw out everything. Yes, I had acute withdrawal symptoms. I broke down and cried sometimes. I became irritable and my energy levels were all over the place. But by the 3rd week, I was much better. It’s been 4 years since and I don’t crave for junk food at all. In fact, I don’t even feel tempted to reach out for a bag of chips in front of me. Once you see the positive changes after you quit junk food, you are even more motivated to continue. TLDR technique (that worked for me): Quit it rightaway. No cheat days, no “just one chip”.Hang on for 3 weeksSnack on healthier stuff instead, like skim-milk string cheese, yogurt with honey, low sugar granola bars, nuts, etc.If you’re craving for junk food to the point of obsession, distract yourself. Play a sport, talk to a friend, play a game…whatever helps. Have a light savory snack like soup instead.Keep yourself well hydrated.Do NOT give in to temptation. I promise it will go away in 4 weeks, tops.Good luck!

I used to be completely addicted to junk food. I tried imagining fast food as really unappetising food, but it didn’t work so well for me. What did work for me, though, was this: I figured out what exactly I was craving. For example, if I really want a KFC salsa twister meal, do I actually want all of the items or just the wrap itself? In this case, I was just craving the actual wrap.I go on Google and find a recipe for at least a close approximation of what I’m craving. So, I search for terms like “kfc salsa twister recipe” or “kfc salsa twister copycat”.I make the recipe and by just a few bites of the dish that I’m craving, the craving goes away straight away. I save money, calories and actually feel good while having the craving disappear. Win-win.I now have recipes for every single fast food dish that I ever craved, with at least almost all of the ingredients being in my pantry. I have found that in the case of craving a certain dish, I think to myself “I can go home and make it myself” but most of the time, the craving goes away by itself. The advice from all of this: Learn to cook your favourite “fast food” items. The homemade versions will almost always be healthier and you can control the ingredients and portion sizes. Plus, you can just make the item that you’re craving without any of the extras that go in a typical fast food meal.Start cooking more in general. I have a wide selection of dishes that I can make, but are not found in their exact form in any restaurant.Fast food cravings can be psychological, in the “you want what you can’t have” sort of way. If you can make it at home, you can have it at any time you want to, as that sort of craving will disappear.Note: I did, of course, talk about the fast food like McDonald’s, KFC…etc. If you crave crisps, you can make your own healthier versions. Sweets is an entirely different ball-game, and the only solution I found to not crave them was to just not keep them in the house.

You have probably heard that old saying "you are what you eat" and you probably understand how eating food impacts the body. When we consume too much of the wrong foods, we can gain weight and become sluggish. I learned a long time ago that no matter how much exercise you do, if you continue to fuel your body with junk, you will not lose weight or improve your health. I'm no stranger to cravings. I have a weakness for sweets. I love cake, cookies, ice cream, candy, and just about any food covered in chocolate. The hardest part is living with someone who keeps the house stocked full of bad foods. Everywhere I turned I was facing temptation! There is a way to conquer junk food cravings even if you live with someone who doesn't eat healthy. Below are some tips that I've put together that may help you eat less junk and more healthy foods. 1. Change where you shop - Local supermarkets are fine but if you live anywhere near a health food market, I recommend shopping there instead. One main reason is that you are almost forced to make healthier choices. These types of markets are less likely to carry cupcakes, cheese puffs, and other tempting items. If anything, they'll have healthier alternatives that will help you as you transition to better eating. 2. Pack your meals in a cooler - If you pack your lunches and snacks in a cooler and leave it in your car, you will be less likely to pull into a fast food drive-through. When you know that you can reach into your cooler and eat something delicious and healthy, fast food will stop being an option. You won't stop out of hunger and desperation. 3. Cook more and eat out less - I know, common sense right? Let me tell you, it really does work. I used to eat out several times a week and mainly due to laziness and feeling like I was slump. Most people have learned through movies or competitive advertisements that places such as McDonald's and Taco Bell can lead to obesity. Still, people choose convenience over health one day after the next. We are encouraged to eat 2000 calories a day or less. This is hard to do with fast food meals. We all know a Big Mac has a lot of calories, but what about when you add in the fries and drink? A Big Mac burger has 590 calories, a medium order fries has 450 calories, and a regular medium soft drink has 210 calories. That equals 1250 calories for one meal. Most people eat at least three meals in a day. It is hard to stay under 2000 at that rate. Many may be fooled by places who claim to be health oriented chains. Take Subway for example. A six inch cold cut combo has 370 calories. That may not seem bad, but throw in chips and a drink and your right back up in Big Mac range. They also lure you into getting the 12 inch option. Most men can eat a 12 inch. That would give you a whopping 740 calories (without cheese or dressing). The same is true for many other so called “healthy options” in fast food restaurants. The issue wouldn’t be so bad if the food offered actually contained nutrition. Calories are bad, but not getting proper nutrition can be just as bad or worse. Try to think of any typical fast food chain that offers an array of vegetables or fruit. It shouldn’t be that hard to think of even one or two. The food offered at these places does not provide us with any of the nutrition we need from foods like fruit, vegetables and dairy products. They are just fillers that make us want more. We are sacrificing our own health for the convenience of fast food. This is a serious problem and is causing a record number of obesity and heart related problems in adults and kids alike.

Changing Your Environment 1Stop buying junk food. Keeping junk food around when you are trying to avoid it is a recipe for failure. If you have lots of junk food on hand, you will be much more likely to eat it. Stop buying junk food and keep it out of your house, car, and office.2Buy healthy food only. Buy whole foods like fruits, vegetables, lean meats, milk, eggs, and whole grains.Selecting foods on the outer ring of the grocery store or foods with five ingredients or less is an easy way to make sure that you are making healthy choices.3Keep plenty of healthy snacks on hand. The more healthy food that is readily available for you to choose from, the easier it will be for you to keep yourself from chowing down on junk.Keep granola bars, fresh fruit, almonds, and low-fat yogurt in your refrigerator and always stash a couple of snacks in your car or purse.4Keep healthy convenience foods on hand. Stock your freezer with frozen vegetables. Stock your pantry with canned beans, tomatoes, whole grain pasta, brown rice, and other healthy staples so that you can easily throw together a pasta primavera or pot of rice and beans. Cooking dinner at home will save you money and it will take about the same amount of time as going through a drive through.Method 2 Changing Your Eating Habits 1Avoid snacking in settings that cause you to make bad choices. Some environments have been shown to increase your likelihood for turning to junk food.For example, if you know that you are more likely to turn to junk food while watching television, have your snack in the kitchen instead.2Eat plenty of healthy food early in the day. The more healthy food you eat early on in the day, the less chance you will binge on junk food later on in the day when your willpower is lower. Start your day with a big healthy breakfast, have a healthy snack like fruit and yogurt mid-morning, and eat a healthy, hearty lunch.3Chew sugar-free mint gum when you get a craving for junk food. Chewing on a piece of mint gum will distract you from your craving. As an added bonus, chewing a piece of mint gum will also make anything that you eat after chewing the gum taste kind of weird, so you will be less likely to continue eating it.4Vary your food choices. Having plenty of variety in your diet will help to keep you satisfied so that you will be less likely to seek out junk food.Pair crunchy items like carrots with something creamy like hummus or peanut butter to add variety into your snacks.5Drink plenty of water. Water helps you to feel full and helps balance your blood sugar. Drink plenty of water throughout the day to keep yourself from reaching for junk food. Staying hydrated with water will also make you less likely to reach for a can of soda or some other type of unhealthy sugary beverage.6Buy a cookbook with easy healthy recipes. Knowing how to cook healthy food that you actually want to eat will help keep you from turning to junk food at meal times. If you are new to healthy cooking, buy yourself a cookbook with easy to follow, appetizing healthy recipes.Method 3 Changing Other Habits 1Distract yourself when a craving hits. Developing other ways to deal with your junk food cravings is also important to kicking your habit. Go for a walk, play with your pet, call a friend, or work on a creative project. Cravings will usually go away if you distract yourself for about 20-30 minutes.2Analyze your desire for junk food when cravings strike. Take a moment to ask why you are craving a specific food. Are you actually hungry or are you bored? Other emotions can make you want to reach for junk food as well. Examine how you are feeling and talk to someone or write about how you are feeling to deal with your emotions rather than burying them in food.3Treat yourself on special occasions. Just because you want to stop eating junk food, does not mean that you won’t be placed in situations where you may want to allow yourself to indulge. If you attend a wedding or birthday party, let yourself have a piece of cake. It’s okay to give yourself a treat now and then!You might even consider designating one day of each week as a “cheat day” so that you can eat some of your favorite foods on that day. Just make sure that you don’t overdo it or you may not feel so great the next day.Kailash Sweets & Snacks4Practice deep breathing or other relaxation techniques. Many people reach for potato chips or candy bars when they are feeling overwhelmed, anxious, or stressed. If you tend to turn to junk food when you are feeling stressed, figure out some alternatives that you can use to help yourself relax. Deep breathing exercises and yoga are great ways to relax.

The other answers tell you what you likely already know - make better choices. You know what those choices are. I’ll take a different approach, to make those choices easier. Set a goal for yourself, write it down, and monitor your progress towards that goal. The goal should require using your body and part of your strategy to reach that goal should include eating better. So if you like running, set a goal to run a 10K in 3 months. If you swim, try to get your mile time under 40 minutes (or whatever is relevant). Get your biking average speed to 20mph for a 30-mile ride. As you train for these, keep track of your weight and performance level. The important thing is that your (attainable) goal is something you’re willing to commit to and work towards. This will give you a daily reason to make good choices, not some vague “I’ll do it tomorrow” reason. Bad choices will have an immediately notable impact on progress towards your goal. Once you’re treating your body like a machine that you need in top condition in order to reach your goal, it’ll be HUGELY easier to push away the bad choices. Another useful tool is to take more interest in finding and preparing the food you like. A good produce store opened in my town a few years ago and in some ways it changed my life. I buy produce when it’s on sale (because it’s in season wherever it comes from) and learn great dishes to take advantage of that particular item. Sautéed spinach, roast cabbage, cauliflower with cheese sauce, and on and on. All kinds of stuff I used to think I hated, I’ve learned that I like a lot when it’s fresh and well-prepared. Once you establish better food habits - and they say 28 days can form a habit - processed or ‘junk’ food simply won’t taste all that great to you anymore. If there’s a favorite item you can't give up (mine is Wavy Lay’s potato chips), go ahead and enjoy it once in a while. No food is really junk if you eat it in moderation. What you really want to avoid is finding yourself eating for the sake of it and not really even enjoying it.

I’ll go against the grain (no pun intended) and say, junk food is addictive, and it’s meant to be so…Food companies manipulate their products (and the advertising thereof) in such a way that one might almost believe chips are good for you…Think about the products that say “Low in Sodium” - yippee! you think to your suddenly health-conscious self (after the doctor said a blood pressure reading measured on a truck scale and a cholesterol count that looks like an atom-smashing centrifuge reading is not good), because less salt must mean healthier eating, but the real darkness hiding in the shadow is sugar… Sugar has been proven to be more addictive than cocaine, and the food companies know this…In fact, they use sugar to help you find ecstasy in food (what they call the “bliss point”)…Using repackaging or subliminal advertising or food sources (i.e. yogurt), they trick us into thinking we’re eating healthy, when we really aren’t… It is indeed good advice to just stop buying it, but there is more to the story…Yes, eating healthy is more time consuming; yes, eating healthy is more expensive; yes, it is easier to shove burgers and fries into your families’ collective mouths so you don’t miss soccer practice/violin lessons/PTA meetings/Anger Management Anonymous meetings and whatever else we’re doing to assuage our children’s disgust or our partner’s unhappiness, but at what cost truly? All of us (me included) are poisoning ourselves and the food companies are letting us commit a slow and cruel genocide with branding and labeling and packaging - and the devil’s tail, sugar… Remind yourself what you are really doing, and keep reminding yourself, and keep reminding yourself…The battle is not won by not stopping at the nearest convenience store so you don’t pick up a package of six sugar-covered mini donuts to accompany your morning cup of commuter coffee…The battle is won by demanding more of yourself…… Good luck

Ah, cravings! Sometimes these can be the pesky little things that creep up on you when you are trying to be healthy and consistent - both in the kitchen and at the gym. Whilst I believe in moderation and never depriving yourself, sometimes a craving that may seem so innocent can end up in a full blown binge that lasts several days or weeks. If you find yourself craving junk food or other bad foods constantly and forever struggle to keep these cravings in check, then read on! Firstly, let’s talk about craving junk food. This generally happens because junk food can be addictive. One of the reasons ‘junk food’ is manufactured is to please people, so that it sells. In order to achieve this, it has to be carefully formulated so that the consumer wants to keep coming back for more, and then we say hello to cravings! When I say that it is carefully formulated, I am talking about everything from how the food looks, to how it smells, tastes, feels like in your mouth and your salivary response to it. All these factors are carefully analysed by scientists in order to create a food that is super appealing to a consumer and leaves them wanting more by tricking their brain into thinking they need it. Junk food is often heavily processed, meaning that they can be full of artificial flavourings, chemicals, salt and sugar, all of which is perfectly measured out to make the food as tasty (and addictive) as possible. It can be really hard to resist cravings when starting a new fitness and healthy eating regime if you are used to eating junk foods on a daily basis. The thing I want you girls to remember is to stop beating yourselves up. I totally understand how hard it can be to beat a junk food craving! It doesn’t help that these foods are specifically created in order to keep you coming back for more, so always give yourself credit when you try to improve your lifestyle. The Less (Junk Food) You Eat, The Less You Will Crave: Whilst this isn’t exactly a tip, I thought I would share it for good measure. Research has shown that the less junk food you eat, the less you will crave it. This may be because you aren’t exposed to the artificial ingredients that lead you to crave it more. If you gradually start to cut junk food from your diet, you can begin to notice yourself craving it less and less, especially if you are eating a wide variety of nutritional foods. Manage Your Stress When talking about cravings, I think it is really important to look at how you manage your stress. For many people, there is a direct correlation between being stressed and eating junk food, and they may not even realise it. Being stressed can cause certain parts of the brain to release specific chemicals such as opiates and neuropeptide Y, which can trigger cravings for fat and sugar. Next time you are feeling stressed or have had a long day, take a moment to reflect back on it and think about what you feel like. Do you chow down on a few pieces of chocolate to take the edge off? Whilst this is okay once in a while, if you use food as a means of coping with stress, you could be eating junk food everyday and not realising the impact it is having on your body. Instead, try to replace eating junk foods with deep breathing techniques, exercise, meditation and distracting yourself. This is one of my biggest tips! Many people want to cut junk food out of their diet and clean up their eating, but they literally can’t get salad and tuna out of their minds. It is SO important to eat a variety of foods so that you don’t get bored. If you crave crunchy potato chips with dip, swap these for carrots and hummus and if you love brownies find a recipe that is refined sugar free and made with natural ingredients. There is absolutely no reason healthy eating has to be boring, it will just take a bit more time than buying pre-packaged versions. Create a Pinterest board where you can store all of your favourite healthy eating recipes so you always have inspiration. Also remember to stock up your pantry with various herbs and spices so you can add flavour to anything. If you always use the same four ingredients in your salads, switch it up! Go to the fruit and veg aisle and try things you have never had before, this is how you make it exciting. Remind Yourself of How You Will Feel Next time a craving hits, take the time to figure out how you will feel after. This goes for both if you indulge in the craving, or if you are strong enough to ignore it. If you indulge in it, but really don’t want to, chances are you will be left feeling guilty and/or sick. I personally don’t like to focus on negative feelings and prefer to focus on the positive ones instead. I like to remind myself about how proud I will feel once the craving has passed and I don’t feel lethargic and bloated. Regardless, try and take that minute’s pause to really figure out if you want to go through with satisfying that craving or not. Don’t Deprive Yourself Ever heard the saying “you want something more when you can’t have it”? Sometimes cravings work like this as well. The more we try to convince ourselves we can’t have something, the more appealing it looks. Instead of totally deciding something is off the cards forever, tell yourself you can have it later. This way you are tricking your brain into thinking you are still going to eat that thing, and chances are by the time the craving passes, you won't want it anyway. Don’t Buy Unhealthy Foods This is a really important one! I know so many people who still buy chocolate bars because they store them ready for ‘treat day’. Out of sight, out of mind is the way I like to look at it. If you don’t have something to tempt you in the first place, you are less likely to eat it. If you have a craving for a chocolate bar, if it is in your cupboard you are more likely to reach for it. If the chocolate bar wasn't in the cupboard, there is the extra effort of having to go get one that may stop you from indulging altogether. Always Have Healthy Options on Hand Sometimes we can’t help it, we want something sweet or salty. Try to keep healthy options near you if possible, so that when a craving hits you can easily eat something else to satisfy it. For example, keep protein balls and raw slices in the fridge and natural tortilla chips in the cupboard so that if you really want to indulge you can, just in a healthier way. I always have apples and bananas in my fruit bowl at home. These are great for snacking on when you are feeling peckish. Eat Wholesome Meals Throughout The Day Many times cravings can sneak up on you when you are hungry. I recommend eating 3-5 wholesome meals daily that are filled with natural ingredients. This can help to keep you feeling full and satisfied throughout the day, and potentially reduce cravings. Regular intake of both complex carbohydrates and lean protein is also important, because it can help keep your blood sugar levels stable and your appetite satiated. I hope these few tips have helped, girls. What are some of your favourite ways to get rid of cravings?

Specify what junk food you want to stop eating and take action. If you have a habit of eating potato chips, like Doritos or Pringles, stop buying it at the supermarket. If you eat at Mcdonalds every weekend, switch it up with another restaurant. Call a friend home and offer to cook them dinner. Or avoid the lane with Mcdonalds altogether so you don’t have to look at it and feel tempted.Identify WHEN you crave junk food. If you have the urge to reach out for certain foods in the evening during your evening TV time, turn off the TV. Go for a walk instead. Watch TV during or after your meals instead, when you’re less likely to crave the food.Don’t stay around junk food. If you’re working around people who’re munching on chips, move to another room. Give away all the junk food you have in your house. While shopping, stay away from junk food aisles.Distract your mind with other things. Answer or read on Quora. Go to the gym or exercise outdoors. Stay constantly preoccupied.Remember that the process is slow and gradual. If you accidentally eat something unhealthy once or twice, it’s not the end of the world. Recognize your mistake and try again. Remember to eat slowly and mindfully, not for the sake of eating or fear that you won’t be able to access it later.Replace junk food with other snacks. Try healthier alternatives like nuts, dry fruits, trail mix or edamame. If you still crave those cakes or cookies, bake them yourself so you know which ingredients go in and can alter proportions(adding less sugar, for instance) rather than buying it from outside. Look at Healthy Snacks: Satisfy the Munchies Sans Guilt | Reader's Digest for ideas on making healthy snacks.Remember that this is a journey. You want to rewire certain habits in your brain, and it’s going to take small steps that will get you where you want to be.

Plan ahead There’s no better way to handle cravings than planning your meals and snacks ahead of time. If you have a healthy meal and snacks packed and ready for you at lunchtime and in the afternoon, you’re far less likely to grab a leftover piece of pizza, order French fries, or eat the sweets someone brought in to the office. In other words, you will reduce your “food cue reactivity.” This is what researchers call your susceptibility to being influenced by the food smells, advertisements, and conversations surrounding you every day. Try to plan out each week’s meals on Sunday, or the day before your workweek starts. Go grocery shopping for what you need. Then prepare large batches of easy foods like brown rice, beans, stir-fried or roasted vegetables, or cold salads. Use food storage containers, mason jars, or foil to pack up serving sizes that you can grab in the morning on your way out the door. Fruits like apples, bananas, and oranges travel well and can be kept on your desk, making them easy afternoon snacks. Shop the perimeter The perimeter of the grocery store typically includes the produce, dairy, meat, and fish sections. This is where you’ll find real foods, rather than highly processed food products. When you go shopping, try to purchase items only from these sections. If a food item has more than a few ingredients on the label (or ones you can’t pronounce), don’t buy it. This is a key step in transitioning your diet to whole foods. Over time, your body and palate will get used to: fresh vegetablesfruitgrainsproteinsYou’ll be getting all the nutrients you need from these healthy foods, so your cravings for the fake stuff will start to diminish. It may take a few weeks, but eventually it won’t even taste good to you! Eat healthy fats One of the most common nutrition myths is that fat makes you fat. In fact, your body needs fat! However, there are many different types of fat. You should avoid trans fats and limit saturated fats, but heart-healthy fats like nuts and avocado will help you feel full and reduce cravings. Have a handful of mixed nuts as an afternoon snack. Or you can make a homemade salad dressing with olive oil and vinegar. Adding fresh guacamole or a fatty fish like salmon to your day is also a great way to incorporate healthy, filling fats. Eat enough protein Protein makes you feel full, often more so than other macronutrients like carbs. Fill your diet with healthy sources of protein including: fishbeansvegetablesnutsWhen you’re full, there’s less room — and less desire — for junk food.

You can do what I did to quit sugar, which was to Read a lot about the negative effects of sugar, but not act on it;Start reading the labels and comparing what you see to a sachet of sugar - a little packet like the ones you see in cafes are 3 to 5 grams;Every time you reach for a snack, ask yourself if you’d be willing to instead eat a sachet of sugar. This leads you to a few possible conclusions. Either you decide that yes, I’d rather eat the sachet, in which case you should just eat a sachet. Less sodium and preservatives, you know? But if the thought of that appalls you - hell no I don’t want to eat sachets of sugar - congratulations, you’ve found an impetus to help you ignore junk food. You can also do what I do to avoid chips/cake/biscuits, which is to Get yoghurt;Get jerky.While the “sugar awareness” trick worked for soda, I wasn’t quite willing to give up other treats as easily. I found that I reached for those when I was hungry and wanted something to substitute lunch. Ergo, if I had better food that was equally accessible and hassle-free (with yoghurt you just have to rinse a cup!), I would still be able to satiate my hunger without having to snack on junk. If that fails, eyeball your pantry and do a mental estimate of how much you spent buying junk food. Take that dollar amount the next time you go shopping and buy a slice of nice cheese and crackers; or a tub of dip; or whatever small health upgrade you’d like to have but don’t usually get. Don’t think of it as “quitting junk food”. Quitting is tough and takes commitment. Think of it instead as “broadening your palette”, because trying new things is fun, and with time you can broaden your palette out of the junk zone and into somewhere better.

Well, you could throw out all you have and not buy any more. Then just start eating healthy "real" food. Yeah, going cold turkey. I can't imagine that would work if you've been eating nothing but junk food and don't really know any other foods or how to prepare them. In that case, learning how to cook and eat right is not going to be an overnight accomplishment. There's going to have to be a lot if education and breaking a lot of patterns. Work with a dietician to come up with a reasonable and not overly complicated food plan. As you are developing your new habits, eating a lot of fruits and vegetables, raw or cooked, will be a simple starter. Keep some fresh food around for snacking at work. There are lots of good books on healthy eating - don't fall for those nutty ones that have you eat a banana before every meal or drink a glass of vinegar every day or eat only what the Pilgrims ate - I'm talking about a balanced diet that will supply your nutritional needs and support an active lifestyle. Look for Michael Pollan's food books. A really good one is In Defense of Food: An Eater's Manifesto. His philosophy is basically "Eat food, not too much, mostly plants". And there are plenty of good beginners' cookbooks. I think Pollan has one of those too. About being active - if you're active and exercising regularly, sometimes there's a psychological event that takes place - the thought that if you've just done something good for your body by working out, you don't want to ruin that by eating something bad for you. In the grocery store, stay away from any EZ to make from mixes foods, which may taste really good, because of all the God knows what that's in them - actually, you do know, it's all on the label - they're full of the things you're trying to avoid by getting rid of the junk food. Mac & cheese in a box, Hamburger Helper, flavored rice mixtures, instant soup mixes, cake mix, etc. Michael Pollan again - stay around the perimeter of the store: produce, protein, dairy. Also, don't go grocery shopping when you're hungry. Junk food really looks appealing then. I don't know if you're including fast food under the heading of "junk," but it might as well be. Again, it's got many of the same ingredients, and in excessive amounts, of the things you're trying to give up. Don't eat in front of the tv or computer - prime junk food eating time. Just as is advised when trying to stop smoking, change your routines. If you have a couple doughnuts with your morning coffee in the kitchen every day, start going in the dining room, having a cup of tea and oatmeal. Remove the circumstances that you associate with junk food. If you and your buddy meet once a week at Taco Bell, start going to Moe's where the ingredients are fresh and you choose the ones you want instead of getting the giant burrito with refried beans full of lard and salt - a couple things that are in the junk you're giving up. Don't torture yourself with the idea that you can never eat another Oreo or potato chip for the rest of your life and feel deprived and miserable. Give youself a break once in a while - and I don't mean a double Big Mac with supersized fries and the big gulp Coke - yes, I know my junk foods and fast foods, just rarely eat 'em. A piece of cake at Mom's birthday party. A few chips with salsa. It's not gonna kill you. And you may find you don't particularly want it any more. Just be conscious of what you're eating, enjoy that little bit, and don't let it send you off to the Haagen Dasz aisle of the grocery store at 2:00 AM. Hope some of this helps get you thru it.

8 Ways to Train Your Brain to Hate Junk Food If unhealthy, processed food, is sabotaging your weight loss efforts, outsmart junk food cravings with these clever tricks. Why do we crave unhealthy food?  iStock/dolgachov As explained in the recent New York Times Magazine piece, "The Extraordinary Science of Addictive Junk Food," there's no denying that junk food cravings are powerful, physiological reactions—and, apparently, carefully and strategically developed by food manufacturers. Many of our favorite supermarket snacks are made with the “perfect” amounts of added sugar, salt, fat, and other chemicals designed to make us want more. But you can steer clear of processed food by eating as many healthy, whole foods as possible, and the less junk food you eat, the less you want. Try the following tips and see if they work for you Practice the five-ingredient rule  If there are more than five ingredients on a food label—a red flag for food processing—don’t buy it. (Or if you do, consider it a treat instead of an everyday purchase). This is an easy way to avoid impulse buys like flavor-blasted chips or pre-made cookies when food shopping. Aim for three colors  A 2012 Cornell study found that people prefer three food items and three different colors on their plates, compared with more or less of either category. So instead of reaching for a candy bar, snack on nuts (loaded with healthy fats), fruit slices, and a small square of dark chocolate to get a healthy variety of colors, textures, and nutrients. Break your routine  It only takes a few weeks to form a habit. So if you always associate 3 p.m. with a trip to the vending machine, start a tradition to walk around the block for five minutes instead. This may kick your craving altogether. Content continues below ad Make healthy food your treat  One of the best, easiest desserts? Stash red grapes in the freezer, and cap off dinner with something sweet without kick-starting sugar cravings. Keep the healthy stuff handy  Store healthy foods you want to eat more front and center in your fridge and out on your countertops. Snack foods are so easy to dig into—you just rip open a bag. If you had, say, red peppers all sliced and ready to go, they’re all the more tempting to dip into hummus. Know your trigger foods  Whether you've got a sweet tooth for chocolate and red velvet anything or love salty treats like pretzels, know the foods that send you down the spiral of junk food binging. You've already accomplished half of the battle by identifying them. Keep them out of the house. Gross yourself out  One surefire way to consume less processed food is to learn more about what you’re really eating. Here are a few that make us cringe: Those frozen "grilled chicken" breasts get their marks from a machine infused with vegetable oil. The preservative BHA is added to processed food like Tang, Kool Aid, and breakfast sausage even though Health and Human Services consider it a likely carcinogen. The vitamin D3 added to many yogurt brands is manufactured from sheeps's grease. And the “natural flavor” in BBQ Baked Lays is made with milk and chicken powder. Yuck! Chew more than you need  Adam Melonas, renowned chef and founder of UNREAL candy (along with Nicky Bronner, a 15-year-old determined to "unjunk candy") shared this smart tip: "If you can make people chew more, they'll eat less." Next time you sneak in a treat, chew slowly and consciously. Wait until you finish one bite to take the next.

Getting out of the junk food rabbit hole may seem impossible. Here are 3 ideas that can help you climb out of that rabbit hole. Take one step at a time with your healing.First, understand one thing, you can overcome your junk food addiction. Unfortunately, western societies are designed for you to keep wanting more. The Standard American Diet (SAD) is laden with bad fats, simple carbs, artificial flavors, and massive amounts of sugar.  Your brain loves sugar. When you have a sugar heavy diet your brain releases feel good neurotransmitters like dopamine. Over time your body becomes addicted to sugar like it would cocaine. In fact, a study done on rats that explored the difference between using sugar water and cocaine as a reward. In this fascinating study, it was found that if drug naive rats were given the choice to receive sugar water or cocaine. after learning the difference between the two levers, 94% of the time the rats chose the sugar water.[1] This is how powerful sugar reacts in the brain of mammals. So if you are finding it difficult to overcome your junk food addiction, this is because you are physically dependent on sugar. There are two options that you can take: Cold turkey- This is the one I did. One day I dramatically reduced my sugar intake. It worked but it was rough in the beginning.Gradually reduce your intake.If you dont respond well to cold turkey the later may be your best bet. You can take one step at a time by: Removing media from your life that promotes junk food.Find healthier foods that you like and gradually replace the junk food.Going grocery shopping each week to ensure longer time success.Surrounding yourself with others that are healing from a junk food addiction.These are just a few ideas of the steps you can take towards better health. Find one positive step to take. Master that step then go to the text. Be kind with yourself and know that setbacks will occur. These setbacks will help you learn why you behave the way you do. Over time compounding will take over. You will be released from the clutches of junk food. 2. Find your triggers. Many times your junk food addiction is part of a deeper personal issue. Perhaps when you were a child love was not abundant. You found food to be a solace for that lack. Using food as an emotional blanket will cause you not to dig deeper and see what's really going on. By ripping off that blanket you expose the real reason why junk food is so irresistible. Yes, this is a extremely painful process. Be willing to cry and feel vulnerable. Know that over time you will be able to better understand and manage your emotions. Through the great pain of uncovering wounds, you will experience healing. You can heal yourself. Make sure you seek support when needed. Support will allow you stay on track. Be patient. Massive progress won't happen overnight. It will compound over time allowing you to live the life you always dreamed. 3. Seek to improve the 4 main parts of your life. As you find what triggers you to eat junk food, you can then start to design a healthier life. These main four areas are: HealthCareerSpiritualityPhysical ActivityThe areas overlap but this framework will give you a great start. For your health you can improve by: Eating whole minimally processed foods.Have a system that include grocery shopping,meal planning, and prepping.Explore areas of self care like massage and holistic healing.For career you can: Make sure that you are completely fulfilled in your work.If not, find time to sit down and see what you really want out of lifeTo start that new life, take one step to work on your new career path in your spare time.For spirituality you can explore: A gratitude or mindful practice.A mediation and affirmation practice.Reading about different ways to heal.For physical activity you can: Find a activity that you love.Invite friends to make it social and fun.Challenge yourself by branching out a trying new ways to work out.The Ultimate Guide to Stop Binge Eating at Night goes into more detail about how you can improve the 4 areas of life and stop eating junk food for good. You have the power to stop eating junk food. By starting your healing process your life will transform in ways you never could imagine. Sources Cited: Lenoir, Magalie et al. “Intense Sweetness Surpasses Cocaine Reward.” Ed. Bernhard Baune. PLoS ONE 2.8 (2007): e698. PMC. Web. 23 Feb. 2018.

Learning how to control food cravings is one of the major keys to successful weight loss. So how do we control those food cravings and get better at it? In one of the study, ‘Food for Thought, 2010’ they had a group of 51 participants (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21…) – They told some of them to imagine eating about 30 M&Ms and going through the whole process. And later they gave them a bowl of candy. Those who had first imagined eating a large amount of M&Ms ate 60% less of the candy on average compared to those who weren’t given the instructions. “Yes, merely thinking of a food, or thinking about cues associated with a food, like how it smells or tastes, does increase our appetite for the food. But if we imagine consuming it and performing the mental imagery that would accompany its actual consumption, imagined consumption can actually decrease our desire for that imagined food.” said Carey K. Morewedge, one of the researchers from the study. Later they found the same effect with an experiment using cheese. A total of 5 experiments delivered similar findings. It seems that simply visualizing eating food and all the sensory cues may trick our brains into believing we’re already eaten some of the desired food. And this would significantly decrease cravings. What’s really happening here is that our mind experiences Habituation. In the context of food, this is a decrease in the responsiveness to the food and motivation to obtain it after you’ve already been exposed to the stimuli. But what we didn’t know is that habituation to a food we crave can occur even when we merely imagined eating it. People simply desired to eat it less, not because they considered the food to be less palatable. Bottom Line: Visualizing yourself indulging in the foods you crave most may actually decrease your desire to eat them. However, be careful not to just think about the food taste and smell, imagine going the through the process of eating it and how that would feel. Thanks for reading!
