Imagine a rubber band stretched between your thumb and index finger for a second. If you pull the middle one way it rebounds back to the other. The harder you pull the more it rebounds. OK, now let’s talk binges, specifically your junk food binges and what the hell rubber bands have to do with it. By the sounds of it, you’re using willpower and putting a full court press with restriction as your form of dieting. With this approach you’re stretching that elastic further and further and it’s starting to look like a slingshot. Then that elastic snaps back making you go H.A.M. on junk food. It’s not you, your willpower, or desire to lose weight…it’s your approach that needs work. The best thing you can do is to leave calories for these junk foods in your days or within your weekly calories. This will help with the “all-or-nothing” thinking and that fear of OMG I’m never going to enjoy food again feeling Depending on your end goal, there is usually some wiggle room to hit up McDonald’s, have that beer or eat the entire King cut prime rib yourself. If you are looking to lose weight, stick to a 90:10 good to bad meal ratio. So, if you are eating 5 meals a day, every day, you can eat whatever you want for 3 meals over the week. Not going off the rails eating where you slam 2 bacon cheeseburgers and a large fry at Five Guys. But have a beer, one bacon cheeseburger, or some ice cream. Even by eating “non-diet” foods you can still lose weight as long as you stay in a calorie deficit. I put together a free fat loss guide if you’re interested.

This is not an Apple advertisement :) To answer your question: simply eat less junk food. Kidding. The thing is there is no easy way to do that. Do you want to stop to eat candies and pastries? Force yourself to not eat them (reduce their amount gradually or drastically). How? Firstly, consider to eat whole and nutritional food. Eat a wide variety of food that also include sugary food such as honey or fruits, salty food such as complex carbohydrates, and so on. When I started to get rid of my cravings of sugary food, there wasn’t a single thing that could work out for me. Then, I realized the reason why I was eating that food was because of many people forced me to eat that food even when I didn’t want it (sunday lunches, easter holidays and so on). Even the advertisement was misleading, so when I turned off the tv I was more detatched from craving processed food (and even from other craps). Eating unwanted food wasn’t a support for my workout sessions as well. I also started to consider a more natural and harmonic lifestyle. I could continue… Stop to eat what people propose you to eat. Eat what you want, when you want, clean and whole food. Eventually, you will realize that a pastry is something unwanted because it’s far than nutritional. Just a bunch a sugar and poor yeast. You will crave real food dude, that’s the truth. Your mindset will change as you will get older. It's about the mindset that will support your lifestyle and your entire growth. Because you are special and you will know what is good for you. What the mass consume won’t touch you at all. Be free to eat, even a lot, but what, when, and how you really want. It’s not about becoming a sort of a monk or a vegan. It’s about finding your balance in an unbalanced society.

The more you read about it, the less you’ll want to eat it. My favorite website for that is NutritionFacts.org. (It has a new video clip daily.) My favorite books include: “Eat to Live,” by Joel Furhman, M.D., “Fast Food Genocide,” by Joel Fuhrman M.D., “Super Immunity,” by Joel Furhman M.D., “How Not to Die,” by Michael Greger, M.D., “Becoming Vegan” by Brenda Davis, a registered dietitian, and “The Vegiterranean Diet,” by Julieanna Hever. You won’t want to eat animals after reading Jonathan Foer’s “Eating Animals.” But you might want to start, as I did, with a middling approach, found in “The Omnivore’s Dilemma,” by Michael Pollan. Modify things you already like, such as chili and tacos, to make them healthier. (Don’t use oil, and add lots of spices instead of salt, and beans of course). Find a great nut-based salad dressing online. I just ground up some sesame seeds in the blender, added orange juice, balsamic vinegar, fresh ginger and a tiny bit of soy sauce. Or try a balsamic glaze, which is just balsamic vinegar reduced till its sweeter because it’s not watery. Fall in love with fruit for dessert, and if you like, blend up some frozen banana chunks, add vanilla, a splash of soy milk and dates for added sweetness to make vanilla “nice cream.” (Add cocoa or strawberries to get other flavors.) Top with toasted pecans. Try not to eat out unless it’s for a salad, and bring your own dressing. Look up words like “whole foods, plant-based” and attend online seminars such as those presented by forksoverknives.com.

First let me say that I completely agree with the answer provided by User-10886366590165570460. But… I thought I would add my two cents in the form of an answer centered on the concept that in a free society, almost everything we do and/or don’t do is a choice. Maybe one very important choice, maybe a series of very small, seemingly inconsequential choices…but nonetheless still a choice. The issue is that many of us only make subconscious choices as we move through life on the path of least resistance. In life, the path of least resistance is almost always a very difficult journey. Coming from a family containing a long line of relatives whom I have termed “eternal teenagers” (adults who still make the same poor choices that they did when they were teenagers, very little changes for them), I have for 46 years observed these eternal teenagers struggle along the subconscious path of least resistance always complaining, wishing and hoping, but never making a single actionable choice which would bring them even a step closer to what they want. There is a complete disconnect between the choices they make and the desires they have. Always blaming someone else. When viewed minute by minute or day by day this path is seemingly easy, requiring virtually no effort. When viewed from a year by year perspective and over a lifetime, it can be depressing, challenging and quite brutal. So to answer your question “How do I stop eating junk food?”, your first step should be to start making conscious, many times difficult choices which will take some level of effort on your behalf. Or in other words, own your choices by making them conscious and deliberate ones by asking “the two questions” each time. 1. What is “it” that I want? 2. What “effort” am I willing to exchange to get “it”? Defining “it”: to eat healthy, to make more money, to exercise, to find a significant other, to go for a walk, etc. Can be anything no matter how big or small. Defining “effort”: deliberate time spent, physical movement or action, gaining knowledge/learning, giving up couch & TV time, applying yourself, withstanding peer pressure and peer ridicule, etc. ______________________________________________ Here is an example from my daily life: Lunch rolls around at work. The path of least resistance is to grab a bag of chips, a sugary treat and a pop. But… I if I diligently apply “the two questions”. 1. What is “it” that I want? I want to eat a healthy lunch.2. What “effort” am I willing to exchange to get “it”? The night before, I will make a choice to exchange a small level of physical activity and what will most likely otherwise be couch/TV time, to prepare a healthy meal to eat for lunch the next day. I will probably also have to endure a little ridicule and peer pressure from my co-workers for trying to improve myself.Actually quite simple once I realize the small amount of effort to achieve this one want. ______________________________________________ I think you probably already have a good idea of what you need to do to stop eating junk food. If not, you should read all of the wonderful responses to your question. But all of the knowledge in the world will be useless unless you are willing to exchange some level of effort to get what you want. So what are you will to exchange for it? If there is nothing you will exchange for that Snickers candy bar or bag of chips, then at least you will have owned your choice and made it deliberately.

These would be my recommendations 1:Eat it daily until you get exhausted with taste fatigue, I am a chocolate addict but after constantly having the same thing on a daily basis I got bored of it and don't bother so much about it. 2:Have lots of alternatives Have lots of options such as fruits, sugar free jello, sugar free drinks, dark chocolate and options like that might be able to help the sugar cravings that you have.  3:Reduce the frequency.Let's say you would be having ice cream 6 days a week, a gradual decrease to start the ball rolling might help. You would be looking at decreasing it to 5 days and week, when you are super confident in sustaining it for 5 days, another reduction to 4 days, and cycle till you don't have it or very minimal intake. 4:Blackmail Diet. The first day, you "simply" enter into an unbreakable agreement that calls for something unpleasant to happen if you don't lose weight. For Bear, it involved money: he put up $5,000 that would all go to the American Nazi Party if he didn't make his weight loss goal. He literally blackmailed himself thin. You don't need money to set up a self-blackmail scheme, as long as you arrange for something negative to happen if you don't lose weight. It works just as well by pledging your time, giving away or destroying beloved objects, writing letters which would cause great embarrassment if mailed, and a whole raft of other possibilities , described here in detail. The Blackmail Diet has nothing to do with food. There are hundreds of diets out there, and they all work. You can lose weight with any or all. Most people begin with enthusiasm, then give up after a few days or a few weeks. They simply don't have the incentive to stick with it. And that's the beauty of The Blackmail Diet. Now you've got incentive. Lose weight or else. It's that simple. The Blackmail Diet: John Bear: 9780898151190: Amazon.com: Books 5:Do not have them at homeNot having any of these foods at home and also to have another alternative back home, if the usual route home has a number of places that causes temptations.

You may be addicted to cheese. To many people, cheese acts like an opioid, which is one of several reasons why corporations like McDonald's continue to do so well.  I hasten to add that the research on the effects of casomorphins on humans is still very conflicting. See: A naturally occurring opioid peptid... [Int Arch Allergy Immunol. 1992] and Review of the potential health impact of β-casomorphins and related peptides. As to how you would go about changing this, whether or not you believe the research pointing to cheese as being a histamine releaser, I would approach the problem as one would the problem of addiction. One strategy for the treatment of addiction is called "harm reduction".  You might start dealing with your addiction to junk foods by  admitting to yourself that, whenever faced with the choice of whether or not to eat junk food, you invariably choose junk food despite knowing the damage it is doing to you; objectively surveying the extent to which it has damaged and is currently damaging your health;devising ways to try to limit your general exposure to junk food outlets, and to rather shop for healthier foods in bulk e.g. on a Saturday morning, prepare it yourself and taking your meals with you, rather than shop for one take-away meal at a time, and very gradually taper your junk food exposure off in a planned, systematic way, by substituting "really bad" junk food purchases with "slightly healthier" junk foods, especially ones that do not contain ample quantities of cheese, saturated fats and salt, and then slowly moving over to healthier and healthier options as you go.

Instead of giving you some non-actionable garbage like “you have to decide if your health or that crappy food is more important to you!”, or similar motivational junk (pun intended), I’ll tell you plain and simple what works. The number one thing is understanding the power of your environment. I talked about this in this video, and the long story short is this: if you believe that consuming a certain food, (like potato chips, let’s say) is not conducive to your goals, then don’t have it around the house. In what situation do you think you are more likely to snack on potato chips, while watching TV: if you need to walk a few steps to grab the bag from your kitchen, or if you need to drive to the nearest store to get it? This brings me to my next point… Master the art of grociery shopping  Shopping seems like a trivial thing, but it’s actually more of an art. Here are the most important steps you need: 1.) don’t go to shopping hungry. Our decision making abilities trend downwards along with our blood sugar levels, so have something in your stomach before you enter the store. 2.) Always have a shopping list that you prepare for yourself at home. Systematically buy the items from that list, and then leave. 3.) Stay away from the isles that are just filled with processed crap. Over time you’ll pretty much know where to go with a closed eye to find veggies, fruits, meats, eggs and protein rich dairy products. No need to look around in the store like a kid in Disney-land:)  Collaborate with people around you If you live alone, the act of keeping things in your house that you don’t need is relatively simple. However, if you’re in a household where others don’t necessarily share your health ambitions, it might be trickier. In that instance, a dose of honesty can come handy, where you just gently fill them into your noble goals of staing healthy/lose weight (or whatever your reasons might be for cutting back on the junk) and then nicely ask for their support. I talked about how I managed this with 2 very non-health conscious (but lovely) Italians I used to flat with. Obviously you can’t force them to not buy those things for themselves, but you can ask them to stop offering it to you all the time, or to put it out of your sight. With this established, you might want to know about the following factoids… 1.) the more you abstain from certain foods, the less you will crave them over time. Eventually, the foods will become less salient in your memory, and the cravings will slowly dissipate. 2.) Your palate changes over time too. People regularly experience this when they get hooked on hyper sweet things - eventually you can get to the point where you need to dump a crap ton of sugar into your tea just to make it feel mildly sweet. If you go without any sweet stuff for a week, even a teaspoon might feel overwhelmingly sweet. 3.) You learn to like the types of foods you regularly eat. Right now fruits, sweet potatoes and cooked carrots might feel like cardboard to you, but over time you’ll learn to enjoy the subtle tastes in these goodies from mother nature. 4.) We are creatures of habit. If right now you have an issue of consuming too much junk food, its because you made it a habit. We are what we repeatedly do, excellence is a habit, not an act. If you really want to geek out on how you can change your eating habits for the better, you can download this long, but epic conversation I had with my YouTuber colleague, Mario Tomic.

Greetings, This is my life’s work, this and reversing disease. It’s difficult to break that habit of eating junk foods! Your question is with merit as it also difficult for most people even here and there to sneak that donut, or that drive-through fast food meal. Good job on asking this! What I do is I write down my goals, I also do a vision board by getting a poster board from the $1 store and glue sticking images on it that I want to bring to my future; I know then, healthy eating has to be a part of all this, right? I buy cantaloupe, watermelon, honeydew, figs, dates, and I often use but not exclusively use Dr. Sebi’s Electric approved food list, it’s vegan and healthful and helps me stay on board. But even before all that, I decided that in order for me to stay on this way of living, I need a solid plan! I did a fresh juice in the morning, juicer, or, blended. You can do that. I also make sure I have a big green leafy salad, or, when the weather gets super cold, I make soups that are simple, easy and healthful. You could even start out with a $1.20 Thai Kitchen rice noodle soup and add in some of your veggies, mushrooms if you like them, and top it off the stove once in your bowl with some fresh chopped cilantro, increasing and upgrading your nutrition. When you’re having a sweet tooth, make some “nice cream” by blending frozen organic bananas, some cacao powder (chocolate) rich with magnesium! and some hemp seeds a bit of coconut oil and freeze it, when ready, put some berries on top and make a quick chocolate fudge sauce even warmed~ cacao powder, coconut oil and a bit of raw agave nectar~ viola~ you’re in! Hope this helps~

If you want to cut out junk food completely, the best thing you can do is ease yourself into it. There are so many tasty recipes out there that are low in carbs and fat, that it really isn’t difficult to eat healthy. It will take some self-discipline on your part, but it is definitely not an impossible feat to transition into clean eating. Here are some tips to get you started: Have a clear goal in mind, such as a date you want to eliminate junk food, a certain amount of weight you want to consume, a number of steps you want to take each each day, or an amount of calories you’d like to stay under. It helps to quantify everything. Consider keeping a journal to track your progress.Remove junk food from your home. I’m not saying you need to raid your home, throwing away every unhealthy food in site, but just stop buying it.Make healthier choices at restaurants. Many restaurants are introducing healthier menu options and are making an effort to be more transparent about what goes into their recipes- if you’re unsure about something, ask your server!Make healthy swaps. For instance, substitute zoodles or spaghetti squash for pasta and cauliflower crust for traditional pizza crust.When you get a craving, change up your routine. We often binge eat when we’re bored, so when you’re feeling a little restless and craving your favorite junk food, do something else instead such as taking a walk.Don’t be too hard on yourself! You will probably experience setbacks, and if weight loss is your goal, you won’t see results right away. Don’t preoccupy yourself with the number on the scale.

Instead of thinking about keeping yourself away from junk food, work to keep the junk food away from you...it won't be around you if you don't buy it and store it.  I suggest you reprogram how you view food...more as a way to nourish and enhance your body and mind and less as a dopamine or drug-like reward.  Schweppes had almost 4,000 taste tests before they came up with the most hyper-palatable version of Dr Pepper possible!  These companies work very hard to make these items impossible to resist and moderate intake.  When Lays said, "I bet you can't have just one", they knew that was the case because of the way they chemically engineered them.  Next, it's very important to reset your car, home and work with healthy, nourishing alternatives like almonds, 85% dark chocolate (I like Green&Blacks organic which has no chemical additives such as soy lecithin), berries, seeds, fruit, greens & vegetables. This step is so important because when you're hungry, angry, lonely or tired you will are now protected from gorging on self destructive junk food if you've removed these items from access.  After 1 to 3 months of this new, clean way of eating...your body will begin to crave these micronutrient-dense, nourishing foods and your cravings for the junk will be a history lesson!  Create new, healthy habits like preparing tea with fresh ginger & turmeric root and slice lemon for your water.  These little rituals will become joyful habits very quickly. This way of living has so many built in rewards as you go along.  Good luck, breath and enjoy the journey~

How many hours are in a day? 24 right? Have you ever planned out what you will be doing for every hour of the day? Some people have their days planned down to the minute for the next month. Wake up at 6 and get ready Work from 8–5 Travel to the gym and Workout 5–7 Make and eat dinner from 7–8 8–10 clean up the house, get ready for bed watch netflix. How hard was that? Now let me ask you a question that is equally measurable as your time. How many calories does your body require in a day? 2000 maybe? Why not plan out everything you will eat tomorrow or even everything you will eat all next week? Breakfast Eggs, bacon, toast Snack Protein bar Lunch Chicken and rice Snack Cheese and crackers Dinner Steak and potatoes Boom done! You didn’t eat junk food for an entire day. Now cook a lot of food on Saturday for the entire week. Put it into containers and throw it in the fridge. Boom done! You didn’t eat junk good for an entire week.  But what if a friend asks you out for dinner? Leave the meal in the fridge and go out with your friend. Order something at the restaurant that has the same amount of calories as the meal you prepared. But what if I get tired of the same food? Leave space in your diet for a cheat meal or a small snack at the end of the day. But what if my house is full of junk food and I can’t stop eating? Throw away the bad food and fill your house with healthy snacks like fruits. But what if my friends and family aren’t supporting my diet? Welcome to life. Are they putting the food in your mouth or are you? Why are you letting haters prevent you from reaching your goals?

First off, there is no such thing as junk food. There are only junk diets. See Is [this food] healthy? Second, as a teenager you should not attempt weight loss except under medical supervision, so see your doctor before you try anything like that. But it sounds like what you really need is an improved relationship with food. A healthy diet is a variety of foods, mostly plants, not too much or too little. Typically the adjustment you need to make is getting more vegetables and fruits in your diet. Here are three scientifically validated methods for tuning your diet: Barriers. Even just moving a bowl of candy out of arm’s reach is shown to reduce its consumption. You know what kinds of foods should form a large part of your diet, and which should form a smaller part. Don’t keep the latter in the house. Just buy the former. It’s easy, and it works.Veggies first. Serve your vegetable course first. That means you don’t even bring the other food to the table until you’ve eaten the salad or whatever veggies course you’re having. That one simple adjustment is demonstrated to increase vegetable consumption.Habituation. To expand your palate you just need to eat a new food every day for about 6–8 weeks. The surprising thing is that small, pea-sized servings are enough. This technique is known as micro bites.Don’t overthink it. And if anybody ever tries to make you afraid of a certain kind of food, tell you it’s junk, or unhealthy, you’ve just identified someone you can ignore for the rest of your life.

Want To Ditch Junk Food? These 5 Tips Can Help You To Start Liking Healthy Food!  Can you actually get yourself to like healthy food? Aspiring to eat healthy is much easier than actually doing it. When it's time to choose between a bowl of crisps or potato chips and a bowl of say, nuts or fruits, we tend to reach for the former. Junk foods have somehow penetrated more than ever in our lives, not just because we have a lot many options than we did before, but also because brands are a lot more sneaky nowadays in positioning junk foods. Marketing campaigns for a number of packaged foods can be incredibly misleading and hide the real nutrition facts of these foods and snacks. But it's more important now than ever before for us to turn to healthy eating, because there is some evidence to suggest that fast foods are unhealthier than they were 30 years ago. A number of common and potentially dangerous lifestyle diseases like hypertension, diabetes, increased stress and even depression have been linked by researchers to diet. There are a number of other factors at play as well, but a poor diet seems to have emerged as a common link between numerous ailments common in urban populations. So how does one practice 'mind over matter' and get themselves to opt for the healthy and nutritious foods every single time? There's a fair bit of practice and discipline involved, but it's something that may actually be done. Healthy Diet: Can you get yourself to like nutritious food over junk food? Here Are Some Ways That You May Actually Be Able To Get Yourself To Like Healthy Food: 1. Do Your Research: There are no tricks involved when it comes to eating healthy - just a whole lot of logic. Reading about the nutritional information of foods may help you turn unhealthy foods down. Shop for groceries and foods mindfully and read the nutrition labels on your food, so that you're aware of what exactly is going in your food. You can then also compare how many empty calories you might be consuming while scarfing down fast foods. 2. Talk To Experts: On your path to cleaning up your plate and eating healthy, you may be confronted with several confusing and even contradictory diet tips. It's best to clarify your diets by talking to a certified nutritionist or a dietitian only. Your nutritionist will also be able to help you with healthy food alternatives of your favourite dishes, along with complete nutrition profile of these healthy substitutes as compared to unhealthy foods. These experts are also more often than not, aware about best brands that sell healthy food products. Healthy diet: Talk to experts about healthy and practical food swaps 3. Plan Ahead: A lot many people fail in their healthy diets because of lack of options to their favourite foods. For example, for someone used to eating Chinese takeout for dinner every single day, may not be able to reconcile their mind with the idea of having a salad everyday instead. You can instead look for nutritious alternatives for say, Chinese fried rice, like a brown rice bowl with chicken. Find out multiple alternatives that keep your taste buds excited and satisfied. Variety can literally add spice to your healthy diet. 4. Surround yourself with 'Health Nuts': Not many people may be fond of someone who is a 'health nut' and insists on talking down to people who like junk food. But keeping such people around may also help you keep a check on the amount of junk foods you're eating. Welcome their criticism of your meals and ask them to give you healthy food swaps for popular foods, as well as delicious ways to cook healthy foods. They might also offer tips that helped them stick to their healthy eating habits. Healthy Diet: Plan ahead and ask your 'health freak' friends for advice 5. Be persistent and treat yourself occasionally: It's important to allow your brain some time to get used to the taste of healthy foods like cauliflower, broccoli, green peas, spinach, carrots, etc. Once you eat them persistently over a period of time, your taste buds get used to the flavour and you may end up developing a liking for even these foods. Treat yourself to an occasional pizza or a cheesy burger once in a while. It might actually help you stay motivated. Once you eat healthy for a long period of time, you will notice certain tell-tale signs of an improved immune system and digestive system, and the quality of your skin may also start improving. Look out for these signs and make a note of them to remind yourself why you started eating healthy in the first place. These 'rewards' are perhaps best for making you like healthy food.

Binge eating is a addiction. Recovery from any addiction is challenging, but it can be especially difficult to overcome binge eating and food addiction. Unlike other addictions, your “drug” is necessary for survival, so you don’t have the option of avoiding or replacing it. Instead, you need to develop a healthier relationship with food—a relationship that’s based on meeting your nutritional needs, not your emotional ones. To do this, you have to break the binge eating cycle by: Avoiding temptation. You’re much more likely to overeat if you have junk food, desserts, and unhealthy snacks in the house. Remove the temptation by clearing your fridge and cupboards of your favorite binge foods. Listening to your body. Learn to distinguish between physical and emotional hunger. If you ate recently and don't have a wrenching stomach, you're probably not really hungry. Give the craving time to pass. Eating regularly. Don’t wait until you’re starving. Fasting and Feasting leads to overeating! Stick to scheduled mealtimes, as skipping meals often leads to binge eating later in the day. Not avoiding fat. Contrary to what you might think, dietary fat can actually help keep you from overeating and gaining weight. Food rich in Fat helps to meet satiety faster with less intakes. Try to incorporate healthy fat to each meal to keep you feeling satisfied and full. Fighting boredom. Instead of snacking when you're bored, distract yourself. Take a walk, call a friend, read, or take up a hobby such as painting or gardening. Hope this will help.

First most important tip: admit to yourself you have a genuine problem with being unable to control yourself around certain sugar, fat, salt laden animal and plant foods. The answer you were expecting? Most people focus on fooling themselves or tricking themselves not to eat these things. They're still addicted, which is why this often just doesn’t work. If somebody is really focused on becoming largely immune to junk food influence, it means admitting compulsions and addictions to these food industry conconctions. The next step after admittal is tolerating (and gaining support if necessary) for the withdrawal period that follows from stopping them, when your tastes and cravings will start to normalise again. Next, planning your eating when out and about. So, when you're exposed to the sight, and smell of these foods, your cravings have reduced and even gone. And finally if you relapse (you probably will, so expect it) getting right back on the horse, not self punishing, and taking responsibilty for your own health in going forward, for whenever you may take a tumble. Many people lack the strength and vulnerability to admit to any of this, but if you're wanting to feel free of the control from junk food, this is what you have to do. Whole food plant based eating is what is best for us, and what we started with: the junk food industries job is to try and make us keep forgetting that fact to keep up their profits, at the expense of our health. See my fave portal Forks Over Knives for more on replacing junk with the foods that are better for us.

We have all struggled with stopping or cutting down on the junk food, so I feel for you! There are a couple things you can try that might help! I have personally tested them all and can verify that it does make a difference and you will feel SOO much better. Go to the grocery store after just eating. If you go on a hungry stomach your eyes will float to whatever you think will satisfy that hunger and craving in the moment. Convienence is dangerous. You will want to grab the chips, processed foods, and things you can easily crack open and enjoy. If you go to the grocery store full, hopefully those impulses to pick up the bad food will be curbed!If you only have good food available to you, you can only eat good food. Going back to number one, if you don’t let the bad food through the door, the food that is readily avaiable to you will probably be good! Throw away any junk food in your house or work that you have access to (don’t throw away your S.O.s chocolates without asking!). Replace the chip snacking with carrots, soda with veggie smoothies, and ice cream with fruit pops. It’s hard, but you’ll thank yourself later.If you go out to eat, package one half of your meal to go before it even reaches the table if you can. Just ask the waiter to make the arrangements, and they will be happy to! And don’t worry about being embarrassed, whoever you’re with will be amazed at your willpower and probably want to do the same! Be a good role model! The portion sizes at restaurants are ridiculous and will break your diet if you’re not careful!Meal prep! You can’t cheat on your diet if you make your days meals ahead of time! Pack in your mix of protein, carbs, veggies, dairy, and more ahead of time, so none of it can be junk! You’ll be full throughout the day, and satisfied knowing you ate healthy the whole time!Hit the gym as well! Seeing progress is what keeps people on a steady diet and gets them to make the lifelong change to be healthy! Hit the gym at least three times a week and work all of the muscle groups to see the difference!Good luck to you and your fitness journey! Come on down to your local Snap Fitness if you want a great gym to be a member with, need a personal trainer, or just want some more advice!

Eating processed foods is a habit which you can’t quit using willpower. How do you quit eating refined food? Here are 10 ways. 1. Have a Reason. Why do you need to quit eating unhealthy foods? Less fat? More health? Lower cholesterol? Have good reason to quit. Write it over a piece of paper & see it every day. This will represent a constant reminder of the goal. 2. Make a Plan. Quitting fast foods means an alteration of lifestyle: What food do you want to eat? What do you want to cook? What can you eat at work? Make an idea that has everything: diet, grocery list, schedule, … 3. Be Confident. Don’t believe the hype. Quitting unhealthy food is easy. Your body doesn’t require it. If it could choose, it’d opt for clean foods. As long as you’re giving one's body what it needs, you’ll be OK. If not: it’s mentally. 4. Take Action. Don’t sit there waiting. If you need to change your diet regime do something about it. Go for the grocery Cook your food Prepare meals for work Common sense, but worth repeating. If the fridge is empty or if you don’t take food to function, you’ll find yourself eating refined food. Be ready, be ready. Take action. 5. Get into Sports. Sport is good. When you get into sports, you’ll possess the tendency to see your nutrition too. Which sport? Up to you. I recommend Strength Training ;-) 6. Choose your Environment. Your environment influences your habits. Choose one which enables you achieving your goals. Remove the processed foods from your house, stop buying it, decline to eating at McDonald’s daily. Read your goals. What’s more valuable for you? Win or lose, your decision. 7. Enjoy Food. Healthy food will not be about eating steamed veggies. Healthy food is tasty, as tasty as unhealthy foods once you’ve adapted. The trick is always to know how to cook. Cooking is often a skill. You can learn it. 8. Eat Junk Food. You don’t should ban unhealthy food from your life. As long as consume healthy 90% times you’ll be okay. One method should be to eat clean over the whole week & then go on a Sunday afternoon junk fest. The longer you consume healthy, greater you’ll have side effects to unhealthy food. Taste adapts. With time you’ll feel special to eat unhealthy food, but you’ll also be happy to go back to clean food. 9. Watch Super Size Me. If you haven’t seen this movie yet, do it now. You’re focusing on the wrong thing. Instead of trying not to eat junk food, try to eat healthy food. I’m sure you remember the food pyramid right? 5 fruits and veggies, 3 servings of dairy and all that? While the food pyramid is too heavy on breads and cereals (which are non-essential foods), it’s a good place to start. Start by trying to incorporate at least three servings of vegetables into your daily diet (but more is better). Try to get two servings of fruits and 2–3 servings of dairy, like yogurt, milk or cheese (processed cheese doesn’t count). Try to eat fish (not battered and fried fish -baked or grilled or steamed) twice per week. Watch your servings of meats. A serving is about the size of a deck of cards. Measure your servings of all other foods according to the packaging. You’d be surprised at how small a servings of cereal or pasta actually is. Only eat one serving of these foods per meal. Make up the difference with healthy foods. Instead of a huge bowl of cereal in the morning, have one serving of cereal with some fruit and yogurt. Instead of a huge bowl of pasta for dinner, have one serving of pasta with a side salad, a steamed vegetable and an ounce of mozzarella. If you get used to eating like this, you’ll find that you eat less and less junk food because you don’t have room to incorporate it into your diet anymore.

The point is to eat foods as close as possible to their natural state. That means either fresh or minimally processed foods and in as big a variety as you can. If you can’t make it at home, it’s probably overly processed. While fruits are sweet, they’re also packed with vitamins and minerals that our bodies need. Refined sugar, and foodstuffs containing it, on the other hand, has been stripped of most of it’s nutritional value and nearly all of the vitamins our bodies need in order to metabolize it. If you have control of your environment, just don’t buy the “junk” foods. If they’re not there, you can’t eat them. The other option is to keep them “out of sight - out of mind”, or locked away where you can’t get at them if you’re living with someone else who persists in buying them. I don’t buy white sugar or white flour. Any cakes or cookies I bake are made with whole grain flour and sweetened with either honey, brown sugar, molasses, or 100% maple syrup, and I control the amount of salt used. I also usually rinse dried fruit before eating it. While real food may seem more expensive, consider what you save by not buying the “junk”. You save not only the cost of the item itself, but also the hidden cost to your health of eating junk food. An optimally nourished person is generally healthy, and recovers quickly from illnesses. A properly nourished person also has good skin and doesn’t need acne preparations or as much makeup. Real food is also more satisfying so if you’re still overeating, you might look more carefully at other factors like portion size, and not eating between meals, or how thoroughly you chew your food. many recipes are written for families, so if you’re living alone, eat one portion and freeze the rest in usable portion sizes. Don’t eat it all just because it’s there.

It’s impossible to lead a healthy lifestyle without considering all other facets of health, happiness and wellness.Hope this helps a little! Sophie Footnotes[1] Sprout | Employee Wellbeing Solutions

In order to stop eating junk food or your cravings you’ll have to understand that it will take time. First, start by setting up a short-term goal such as not eating junk food for 3 days. It’s a lot easier to hit your short-term goals than long-term goals like going without junk food for a week. By completing short-term goals, you’re also giving yourself a self-confidence boost each time you complete a goal. Second, if you’re feeling hungry or craving junk food then try drinking a cup or two of water instead. Many people misinterpret dehydration for hunger. It’s very common for people to be dehydrated these days and you’re most likely not drinking enough water. By drinking water, you’ll be able to keep yourself full most of the day, stay hydrated, and deal with your cravings. Finally, find alternatives to junk food. I’m not saying just start eating fruits and vegetables right away because that won’t work. You have to slowly ease yourself into the process of cutting out junk food. By having alternatives such as Baked Lays instead of regular Lays, or sugar-free ice cream instead of regular ice cream, you’ll be able to eat healthier items dealing with your cravings. I recommend counting calories with MyFitnessPal because if you’re worried about gaining weight then you’re probably overeating. If you track your calories then you can see if you’re overeating or not. Then you can adjust your calories to lose weight. Check us out to learn more and even incorporate fast food to lose weight: Best Way to Lose Weight and Fat as Fast as Possible

First, define junk food. Do you mean fast food like hot dogs, or do you mean sugary food? If the problem is fast food, I can’t help you. If the problem is sugar … I’ve been fighting my sugar addiction for 50 years. You can win. You can also lose it all. So first, I want to caution you that if you succeed in getting off the stuff and then return to it, getting off it again is even harder. This is what I do: Take a sheet of paper and write on it: “Sugar makes you want to do nothing … Except eat more sugar.” Post it on your refrigerator. Because that is indeed one of its effects. And this is one of the reasons it’s so hard to shake - it’s literally the only thing you want to do.Eat. Eat all the time. Anything that isn’t sweet. Fat is your friend. Meat is good. Vegetables are better for you. Don’t eat fruit. Do not increase your intake of flour-based foods: bread and pasta.Give yourself time. Recognize that life will be horrible for at least three days. The first day is the worst. Don’t plan on doing anything. Watch TV all day. By the fourth day you can plan on resuming your life.Incredibly, by the end of the first week, you will rediscover interest in a lot of things you had forgotten about.

The best solution is different for everyone. You need to know what your triggers are. For example when and where do you find yourself eating junk food? Is it all the time? Is it between meals? Is it when bored? Is it because you can’t cook? etc. For starters whenever you go to the supermarket make sure you have just eaten (something healthy). This reduces the chances of you buying rubbish at the supermarket. If junk doesn’t get into your house, you won’t eat it when bored etc. If you don’t know what healthy food to eat or don’t know how to cook it - that’s a learning, information and attitude issue. Learn how to cook healthy food in a way you like and cook enough for the entire next day…or even the next week. Having your food pre-prepared reduces the chances of you buying and eating junk. As others have said, have healthy snacks with you at all times. Ideally they should be protein based (like a bar, shake, pre-prepared chicken, etc). Fruit is ok but it can just make continual sugar cravings worse. Nuts are good for you but are high-calorie, so it’s a case of managing your intake. All of the above are tips, tricks and tools but first you need to make a clear decision and commitment. You then decide what your tactics will be to make sure the commitment happens (these are what I’ve described above). In short, think about every situation where you eat junk food, determine the root cause of each particular instance, and find a tactic that satisfies the root cause. Hope this helps Andy Fitbodystrongmind.com

In my opinion, one of the biggest triggers for eating junk food is restricting it. When we tell ourselves we can’t have something, we automatically want it more. Think about it, if someone placed a piece of chocolate cake in front of you but told you you couldn’t have it, you would only want it more. There is nothing wrong with eating ‘junk food’, as long as it makes up a part of a healthy and varied diet. Perhaps you can select one day a week that you will allow yourself to have ‘junk food’. For example, you may decide that Friday nights you will allow yourself to have pizza or a burger. Or maybe Sunday nights you will have cake or chocolate for desert. The important thing to remember is that there is nothing wrong with ‘junk food’- it is about moderation. I myself have some form of ‘junk/unhealthy food’ everyday, but I junk limit my serving size. For example, after dinner I often enjoy a chocolate biscuit or a couple of squares of chocolate. By allowing myself to do this and making no food forbidden, it ensures that I do not end up binging on large amounts of junk food. Another thing I find useful is to ensure that I have a good supply of nutritious and healthy food available at all times. I ensure that I have fruit, vegetables and healthy snacks in the fridge; I make my lunch for work; I bulk cook a variety of healthy meals to freeze for dinner during the week and always bring a couple of healthy snacks in my handbag in case I get hungry. Of course, this can take a bit of preparation, but at the end up the day it ensures that I am getting all the nutrients I need and am not resorting to ‘junk’ foods for all my meals. At the end of the day, food is one of the pleasures of life and should be enjoyed. Don’t restrict yourself- everything in life is about moderation.

Your surest way is to come to terms with yourself. Ask yourself who am I? And then if you realise you are not a junk food eater you can and will be true to yourself and stop eating junk food. You will be who you are. We all do that. Sometimes it is called living up to your self image. Whatever you call it that’s what we do. It gets confusing when people have no clear self image. They can’t then be said to be living up to it, can they? When you don’t know yourself how can you be true to yourself? These are semantics. Word games. The point is you are whatever/whoever you currently are and you’ll continue to be this and do this until ever you take a look at yourself and decide that you don’t want to be this, don’t want to do this. This is in distinction to accepting yourself as you are and maybe even being proud of it - and setting that self the task of eating less or eating differently. You may or may not have success in that task. But once it is completed you will revert to being ‘who you are’. That is: that person who habitually eats junk food. It is easy for that person to not eat junk food. More word games. Don’t eat this morning. Okay you’ve done it. You didn’t eat junk food. Now eat this afternoon. And so on. Presumably you mean never eat junk food. Well you - the ‘you’ you currently are - will never reach that state. If you did you’d be a different ‘you’, see? This is what happens to dieters. They want to remain who they are - perhaps a person whose whole life is dominated by thoughts of food and satiety and gormandizing even gluttony - but get the weight off. A hopeless task. Once they get some weight off they breath a huge sigh of relief and revert to eating what they like. But think people simply don’t eat that much. They are not that kind of person. You must change who you are. Which you can’t really do. None of us can. The innermost heart dictates all. But the good news is that the innermost heart of us all is generally healthy, fit, happy, intelligent, etc.. a whole paragon of virtues if you like. We get an intimation of that in the fact that we all know we’d all like to be fit, healthy, sensible, intelligent, virtuous, etc.. wouldn’t we? So take a good hard look at yourself. Search within yourself to find a desire to be a person who doesn’t eat junk food. If there’s no such desire to be found you’ll never make it. But if there is then it is only a question of being that person. ‘To thine own self be true’ it is written. Search yourself. Figure out who you are and then be you. If you’re not a junk food eater then the junk food will remain uneaten.

Have you ever had to break a bad habit like biting your fingernails? There is a stage when you have to be hyper-conscious about your behavior. You need to somehow make your self pay attention and be aware of every bite you eat. Consciously and against your urges, say NO to your craving. It can be difficult. You have to find a motivation within yourself that is so powerful and so important that your reason wins your internal argument every time. Once you figure out your motivation to quit junking, give that reason to the “little voice” in your head: the voice you argue with when trying to talk yourself into or out of something. Give your voice power: own your motivation, absorb it, live it. Make it important. The grocery store is a control point: don’t ever go shopping hungry. Don’t go down that aisle. Don’t bring the junk home or have it in your home at all. Avoid vending machines. If you are at a party, park yourself away from the junk table. After you’ve been “off” the junk long enough, your cravings will gradually diminish. You’ll still need to be aware and strict with yourself in the vicinity of junk, but it will become easier. When I ate too many chips after a long period without, I felt so icky later that I “attached” that memory to my “motivation voice”. KNOW that you can do this, and do it!

response.answer_text: It depends on *why* you’re eating junk food in the first place. Are you… Eating to fill up void in your life?Experiencing heavy cravings for junk foodAlways hungry, but can’t find the time to eat healthier alternativesSimply eating out of habitYou don’t know whyNow obviously, individual strategies that people have listed are going to help; but if you don’t dig deep into the root problem. You have a higher risk of using a less effective (or worse, ineffective) plan. If you are eating because you’re sad, or because there’s a void in your life, you might find that going to a therapist, or doing fufilling things in your life will help. Volunteering for the homeless, or at an animal shelter, or for human rights are some suggestions. If you experience heavy cravings for junk food, one reason (likely reason) might be that you don’t have a healthy balanced diet, or that you are eating out a psychological craving due to your eating habits. Also meaning you don’t have a healthy balanced diet. When we don’t have enough fats or salts, we tend to crave it so strongly that by the time we do get fats or salts, we indulge heavily. If you’re always hungry, and have no alternatives… you’re going to just have to bite the bullet and find healthy alternatives. It’s hard at first, but it gets easier as you learn what’s good and what’s not. More things are good for us than many people realize. If you’re eating out of habit, you’re just going to have to throw out all the stuff in your house and living place. Psychological studies have shown that humans have a limited capacity to make decisions. If you keep seeing chips, or junk foods; you might be able to say no the first couple of times. But most people give in by their 200th no. If you don’t know why you’re eating so much junk food, you might want to visit a nutritionist or do some deep introspection. Adopt some of the above strategies or ones that other answers have recommended. Good luck :)

Find something healthy you dont mind snacking on e.g. fruit, nuts or veg and have it easily accessible throughout the day. This prevents those trips to the vending machine or the drive through. For me, Iove snacking on carrot. Either a full one or carrot sticks. You'd be surprised by the time you're done a whole carrot how much you've curbed those munchies. If you can, go cold turkey for a while. I find if you dont buy it and its not in the house than you cant have it even when you want it. Eventually you stop missing it. So that when you can loosin the reigns a little your body doesnt enjoy it the way it used to and you are more likely or capable of just having a small modersted amount or just saying no thanks altogether.

Some strategies to help you if you don't have the will power to stop yet. Find a motivator. Obviously you want to stop, but this desire isn't motivating you enough to break the habit. Do you feel unattractive physically? Try to calculate in your head how much weight you would lose if you ate one less bag of chips every week. One less cookie a day. Or cut out soda/juice. Another common motivator is money. If you spend $5 a day on food you consider junk, that's $35 a week, $150 a month, or $1800 a year. For $35 a week you could go out to a nice restaurant and have something even more delicious made for you as your one junk treat instead of things you might not even enjoy much anymore, daily. For $150 a month you could be working something like 10–15 hours less at a job and have more free time, buy a new computer, or finally get that thing fixed on your car or home you could never afford. For $1800 a year you could take vacations. Buy something big like a pool, or a game console, take some higher education classes toward your degree, or just pay of any debt you have. Pit that against a cookie at lunchtime and it doesn't look so yummy anymore.That first one was pretty long so I'll keep this one short. Out of sight out of mind. Sometimes you just can't avoid your vice but this will really help. Get all the junk out of your home, your desk or locker at work, your car, your LIFE. If it isn't available every single time you have a craving, you'll give in to those cravings less. And if they're not around every time you walk through the kitchen, you don't see it and go “ooh yum, ok just one”. It's a cycle and you're breaking it. You'll stop binging ice cream at 2am because the store isn't even open to go buy some, and driving to the 7eleven for a coke every time isn't worth the effort or the money. Also avoid places you tend to buy unhealthy foods at. You can't avoid walking by the vending machine at work, but if your coworker wants to stop by Starbucks for coffee at lunch, and you know you'll buy a muffin and a milkshake if you go, politely decline, or suggest going somewhere else. Simply avoiding familiar situations that you will default into habit behaviors will stop you from engaging in those behaviors most of the time.Cold-turkey isn't always the way to go. Feeling deprived can make you unhappy and end up just binging on a bunch of these forbidden foods all at once, then you'll be unhappy for a different reason. Find alternatives that aren't quite as bad. Used to cookies at lunch? Try a granola bar, or even just a trail mix with minimal sweet components like cocolate. Or a good option is to have “cheat days” where it's ok to have one or two junk foods as long as you have stayed true on the rest of the days. Or a different kind of treat as an incentive, like when we talked about money. Save what you would have spent on junk all week then use it for whatever you want, a new pair of shoes, drinks with friends, a date night, or even going out to a restaurant and getting something not-so-good for you, but very satisfying. This way you can look forward to it all week and thing of it every time you go. For that comfort food or sugary snack.

My first ever A2A - thanks! First, make sure you are getting adequate nutrition every day. Try using a food tracker app or website to see what you're eating, and use the analysis tools to check that you are getting enough calories overall for your particular body stats (age, gender, height, weight, activity level). Check also that you're getting enough protein and fiber and a good balance of carbs and healthy fats. Not too much sugar, but don't cut it out cold turkey unless you want to snap at everyone around you. Second, do some introspection. When is it that you are eating junk food? Is there a particular location or time of day that you find more difficult? Use the "HALT" acronym (Hungry, Anxious, Lonely, Tired) to determine what need it is that is going unmet, which you're trying to fill with junk food instead. Are there other ways you can meet that need? Try to anticipate your own needs so you can work on meeting them earlier, before your body starts to panic. Third, recognize that willpower is a finite resource every day. Where you can, try removing the temptation rather than forcing yourself to overcome it. Pack healthier snacks (vegetable sticks, nuts, yoghurt, etc). Carry your own water so you don't get thirsty, if soda is a problem for you. Clear the junk food out of your house and office, or at least pack it away so you aren't reminded about it constantly. Don't deny yourself all junk food whatsoever or your willpower might run out before the end of the day. Rather work on gradually creating healthier habits. Fourth, be kind to yourself if you mess up. Your body is a good body. It is working hard for you. Celebrate your successes and don't dwell on your failures, and you will be surprised how much more your body will be willing to do for you.

Stop buying it. It is easier than you think. Youre at the market, use 5 minutes of will power and don't buy ______. But you crave sugar. Pick a fruit any fruit and buy that. Then leave. At home, “I desperately want sugar”. “All I have is this fucking apple”. I eat one and still unsatisfied. So I eat a second. Unsatisfied but now I am full and eating anything else would make me sick. Wash rinse repeat. Bad week: I buy a container of chocolate covered almonds becuase “hey at least it has protein” and then dump half in the trash can, leaving me at best a handful. I am not going to dig out the almonds from a trash can so I better savor those 12 chocolate covered almonds I have left or else the rest of the week will suck. Nibble on that one almond. Enjoy it's chocolately warmth on my tongue. It took me 5 minutes to eat one almond and hands have half the chocolate so I use a napkin next time. If you’ve only been eating junk food and prepared slop, then you probably have something akin to a salt and sugar addiction. Your taste buds are compromised, poor things. Going cold turkey probably won’t work, since healthy, non-over sugared and over salted food will taste bland to you. So wean yourself off the salt and sugar gradually. You’ll need to incorporate meals into your diet that are big on flavour to substitute the buzz you get from all that white stuff. Try homemade Italian tomato sauces with pasta, Indian curries and other highly spiced ethnic foods. Most of these have lots of vegetables so you’ll be off to a running start. Don’t ever think healthy food can’t taste good. Look for the best quality, freshest foods that are available. Don’t rely on prepared food when homemade is just as easy: salad dressing is a good example. Mix up some olive oil, vinegar, a dash of mustard in a glass jar and shake away. Tastes soooo much better than the sweetened versions you get at the supermarket. You don’t have to give up salt and sugar— they enhance the flavour of food. Just monitor your usage. See if a salt substitute works for you (but don’t think that is a license to overdo it). Sugar substitutes are to be avoided. Keep on enjoying your chocolate cake but just don’t have it every day, and keep the portions reasonable. There is quite a lot of information out there, but do look for basic information first, and try to stay away from strict or trendy diets. A Mediterranean diet, for example, sounds delicious and healthy, but it’s hard to maintain if you don’t have a garden (for really fresh veggies like the Europeans eat!) or access to fresh fish. It is all a balance of what you like, what you can afford, what is available, and what is best for your health. Have fun on the journey!

Get yourself in the mood by watching low carb and kicking sugar and fructose vids on youtube. (I’ve linked to a couple at the end of this post.) Become an expert. Look up all the pros and cons. Work out what you have to avoid: pastry, bread, rice, potatoes, sugar, grains, excessive fruit, and where this stuff lurks. Read low carb high fat recipes on internet sites, such as how to make cheesecake and cream with stevia. Educate yourself about cooking. Have some solutions to eating when you are out: steak, cream, nuts , cheese, sausages without wheat in them, the inside of meat pies, the top of pizzas, fish, shellfish, calimari (you can get rid of the batter). There is a lot of stuff around, most of which people on ‘moderation’ diets try to avoid. I find that Chinese restaurants have high protein and fat dishes and will serve you food without rice if you ask and are sometimes very generous with the portions. Avoid TV stations that advertise food, or advertise at all, if you can. Learn about addictions (youtube again) because the sugar fat combination in junk food is addictive. The fat is okay, but mixed with sugar, is terrible. If all goes well, you will learn to recognise when you are hanging out for a sugar hit and substitute something sweet without cals, such as stevia or aspartame sweetened soft drink or milk drinks. Or just go for a walk, dance, listen to music, romance someone, buy some clothing that fits for a change. :-) (In the US there is a new brand of high fat no sugar icecream called Rebel or something like that, I have just read. ) Eventually you will begin to understand that these sugar siren calls are not worth responding to and they will go away. You won’t miss sugar or starch. I find the smell of cakes and bread a bit sickening these days. We get used to it, but it is not really very pleasant. Good luck! Some vids that helped me: Dr Lustig of U of California’s work on fructose (a kind of sugar in just about every processed food that hooks us in.) Just looked for some good stopping sugar ones but there is so much junky video there, you need to trawl for your own. The one that got me was short and simple, with a woman saying, “You get up in the morning and you have some toast. Your insulin goes up and sets off the cravings.” So, I stopped eating toast in the morning or at all. I actually didn’t suffer much at all.

To stop craving bad foods aka junk food you must infuse herbs (into your diet) they are the best source of anti-oxidant. For the most part our bitter and sour receptors have been repressed so much that we can barely stand to consume foods and beverage that benefit us. For a healthy body & mind we must introduce herbal: tinctures, bitters, teas & formulas to our dietary regime. Regardless of what mainstream ‘experts’ say I know from personal experience that herbs are an integral part of nutrition. So if you are serious about giving up junk food forever eat real foods sourced from plants mainly, a bit of red meat is fine and then load up on herbs it cannot be over-emphasised Good luck and Be well

Here are few tips which could help you to make healthier lifestyle choices: 1. Nourish your body with love.There is a big difference between making lifestyle changes because you love yourself and you want the best for you and because you hate your body and can’t look at yourself in the mirror. Choose the love instead of restricted diets, starvation, and deprivation. Be kind to yourself and take care of yourself with love. You deserve it. Don't feel bad after you ate something your think you shouldn't eat. The guilty feeling leads to eating another comfort food and cycle repeats again. Enjoy everything in moderation.2. Balance your diet.Eat regularly, don’t skip meals or restrict your diet because you ate too much the day before. Stick with three main meals with two healthy snack between. Make sure your food includes complex carbs, protein, healthy fats and plenty of fresh fruit and vegetables. The healthy eating plate is a helpful tool when you are not sure how to combine your meal.3. Eat more protein.Protein will keep you full and your blood sugar level stable. So even you feel like the chocolate cake in the afternoon have handful of raw nuts or hummus with veggie sticks instead.4. Prepare healthy snacks ahead.The best way to make healthy food choices during your busy days is “being prepared”. Invest the time in yourself and pack some snack ahead so you can grab them whenever you are hungry. Here are few Healthy snacks options which satisfy your hunger and give you long-lasting energy. And they are delicious!5. Prefer healthier options.Instead of store-bought chocolate bars make your own chocolate with cacao powder. Raw desserts packed with nuts and dried fruit are also great for you. Or keep it simple and grab a piece of fresh fruit.6. Keep sweets out of the house.Easy right? If you don’t have it at home you can’t eat it!7. Track your feelings.Keep a food journal and put down notes how do you feel before and after every meal (hungry, bored, exhausted, satisfied, sick, bloated etc.) It’s the best way how to see your food patterns and find the triggers of eating comfort food.8. Practice mindful eating.Eat your food with awareness. Don’t eat quickly behind your desk or when you are running on the street. Sit down. Chew slowly. Enjoy every bite.9. Spoil yourself. Occasionally.From time to time spoil yourself with the dessert you love and enjoy it! The life is short and occasional treat is completely fine.10. Regular exercise.Being active is good for your body and mind. Choose exercise wisely. Do what you really like to do, what you are looking forward to do. Pick the right exercise, that you can stick with for a long-term period.11. Do what you love, what makes you happy.Pursue your passions and hobbies. Now it’s the best time! Start your dream business, explore new hobbies, or meet new people. Put yourself first and welcome new adventures. Take it slowly.Make small changes in your lifestyle (1-2 per week).Don't overwhelm yourself and enjoy every step! Hope it helps :)Wishing you all the best! Magdalenahttp://www.magdalenamandryk.com

The first step whenever you want to improve your diet is to take note of what you are eating, including impulsive snacking. When you’re aware of what’s going into your mouth, pinpoint the worst of it and figure out a healthy alternative -kind of like switching to silly phrases instead of cursing. For a lot of people, that first thing is sodas and sugary drinks. Start carrying a reusable water bottle so you always have something when you’re thirsty, and when you’re not simply thirsty make a conscious decision to look for healthier alternatives such as tea, milk, vegetable juices, or just water of different temperatures (I like a glass of warm water first thing in the morning.) In addition to using water to curb your taste for sugary drinks, keep carrot sticks, whole fruit, or nuts on hand for quick snacking. If you don’t know how already, learn to cook. It’s very difficult to make food from scratch that’s as bad for your health as commercially processed foods. Start with something easy, like eggs or soup, and progress onto whatever sounds interesting. Read different recipes for the same thing and watch Youtube videos to help you learn. Grab a friend because the kitchen is so much better with company! When you master a recipe the way YOU like it, write it down in a notebook as your own recipe book, like a true chef!If you don’t have a lot of time to cook, make sure you set aside time once a week to prepare large batches of a couple foods like curry or soup and divide these into servings in the refrigerator or freezer to microwave later -it’s faster to microwave leftovers than to stand in line at a fast food joint! Eventually, eating healthier will also change your taste preferences and make junk food that much less appealing. READ! There are lots of books on healthy eating from Nutrition and Physical Degeneration (The first half isn’t as boring as it sounds, I promise) to Natural Born Heroes, to The Omnivore’s Dilemma. Reading books on healthy eating tell you what’s good for you and can help make junk food a lot less tempting. And; go easy on yourself. It’s hard changing your diet and nearly impossible to do it in one go. You’re not going to ‘destroy’ your goals if you grab a slice of cake to celebrate an important event or hit Jack in the Box after you’re week’s gone to $#!+. The point is to keep working at it, keep doing better, and eventually it will get easier. Don’t give up!

This might sound aggressive, but think of conventional supermarkets like Casino’s, trying to lure you in and get you to buy crappy processed food, aka junk food. They do not have your best interest at heart. Take control of your health! The point is, this is hard! We are in a time of immense nutrition discussion. Food has become as polarizing as the 2016 presidential election. We know what we love and what we hate, but are unable to agree on anything in-between. Love it or hate it, food culture is actively shaping your life and silently shaping your health. It has a bigger impact on your finances and lifestyle than any other factor in your life. There is not only an economic gap in this country, there is a massive nutrition gap — or maybe they are becoming one in the same? Here is what you can do about it: Connect yourself to your food. Eat and cook more meals at home. Buy and prepare fresh organic whole foods. If you can’t pick it up, smell it and know what it is, run away. Think vegetables, nuts, and meats. CLEAN, CLEAN, CLEAN.Surround yourself with people who can support you. It’s nearly impossible to reach your goals without a healthy supportive environment. Find friends, family or communities that live and breath healthy values and lifestyles.If you need some help, check out Corevity - a place you can share and articulate your health story and get the support you need. Use time and home cooked meals to your advantage. Similar to what someone quiting smoking does, fill your brain with other stuff like painting, homework, house cleaning, etc. when you crave junk food. The goal is to pass time and get the thoughts out of you. Home cooked meals are good because if done right, you can make similar foods like a burger or a burrito, but you have control over the fat and sugar content. Basic point here: you don’t need to stop eating burritos to be healthy, you just need to stop eating them from Taco Bell. You would be amazed at the things that you can make healthy at home that would otherwise be 2,000 calories at a restaurant. Your body feels better after a home meal, too. Quick term solutions: drinking lots of water helps, this is a teaditional answer to your quesrion and it does work to some degree depending on your metabolism. Snacking on thungs like carrots or foods high in fiber also help fill you up. You should eat a cup of carrots if you desire junk food. There is also medication that can block specific brain receptors to suppress appetite. You’d want your doctors advise on that though.
